en_test: Several years ago here at TED, Peter Skillman  introduced a design challenge  called the marshmallow challenge.
zh_test: 几年前，在TED大会上， Peter Skillman 介绍了一个设计挑战 叫做“棉花糖挑战”
M2M100: 几年前,在这里在TED,彼得·斯基尔曼介绍了一个设计挑战称为马斯马洛挑战。

en_test: And the idea's pretty simple:  Teams of four have to build the tallest free-standing structure  out of 20 sticks of spaghetti,  one yard of tape, one yard of string  and a marshmallow.
zh_test: 是个非常简单的主意 要求一组四人的团队搭建一个独立的最高建筑 材料是20根意大利面条 一段胶带，一段绳子 一块棉花糖
M2M100: 这个想法很简单:四个团队必须从20块蜘蛛、一块绳子、一块绳子和一块火柴中建造最高的自由站式结构。

en_test: The marshmallow has to be on top.
zh_test: 棉花糖必须放在最上面
M2M100: 马歇尔必须在顶部。

en_test: And, though it seems really simple, it's actually pretty hard  because it forces people  to collaborate very quickly.
zh_test: 这虽然看似简单，其实并不容易 因为它要求人们 迅速地合作
M2M100: 虽然它看起来很简单,但它实际上是相当困难的,因为它迫使人们非常快地合作。

en_test: And so, I thought this was an interesting idea,  and I incorporated it into a design workshop.
zh_test: 我觉得这是个有趣的主意 我把它放到了设计专题讨论会上
M2M100: 因此,我认为这是一个有趣的想法,我把它纳入了一个设计研讨会。

en_test: And it was a huge success.
zh_test: 结果非常成功
M2M100: 这是一个巨大的成功。

en_test: And since then, I've conducted  about 70 design workshops across the world  with students and designers and architects,  even the CTOs of the Fortune 50,  and there's something about this exercise  that reveals very deep lessons  about the nature of collaboration,  and I'd like to share some of them with you.
zh_test: 从那以后， 我在全球 70多个设计专题讨论活动中 让学生们和设计者，建筑师 甚至财富50强的首席技术官 这个练习在很多方面给了我们 深刻的启迪 教会我们合作的特性 在这里我跟你们分享一些
M2M100: 从那时起,我与学生和设计师和建筑师,甚至Fortune 50的CTO,在世界各地举办了大约70个设计研讨会,这项练习揭示了关于合作的深度教训,我希望与您分享一些。

en_test: So, normally, most people begin  by orienting themselves to the task.
zh_test: 通常， 人们总是从 讨论开始着手完成这个任务
M2M100: 因此,通常,大多数人开始将自己转向任务。

en_test: They talk about it, they figure out what it's going to look like,  they jockey for power.
zh_test: 他们讨论一阵， 勾勒出结果会是什么样子 他们互相争论一番对错
M2M100: 他们谈论它,他们知道它会是什么样子,他们为权力玩耍。

en_test: Then they spend some time planning, organizing,  they sketch and they lay out spaghetti.
zh_test: 然后花费点时间计划，组织 他们画一下图纸然后拿出意大利面条
M2M100: 然后,他们花了一些时间来规划,组织,他们绘制,并放出垃圾桶。

en_test: They spend the majority of their time  assembling the sticks into ever-growing structures.
zh_test: 他们用了大量的时间 把意大利面条组装得越来越高
M2M100: 他们花了大部分时间把<unk>子聚集在不断增长的结构中。

en_test: And then finally, just as they're running out of time,  someone takes out the marshmallow,  and then they gingerly put it on top,  and then they stand back, and -- ta-da! --  they admire their work.
zh_test: 然后最后，时间快要用完了 他们拿出棉花糖 小心翼翼地将棉花糖放到最上面 然后他们后退一步，哈哈 他们欣赏着他们的成果
M2M100: 最后,正如他们走出时间一样,有人拿出火柴,然后他们轻轻地把它放在上面,然后他们站了起来,他们 - 达! - 欣赏他们的工作。

en_test: But what really happens, most of the time,  is that the "ta-da" turns into an "uh-oh,"  because the weight of the marshmallow causes the entire structure  to buckle and to collapse.
zh_test: 但是绝大多数时候，真正发生的是 “哈哈” 变成了“糟了” 因为棉花糖的重量把整个结构 给压散架了
M2M100: 但真正发生的事情,大多数时候,是“ta-da”变成一个“uh-oh”,因为火柴的重量会导致整个结构崩溃和崩溃。

en_test: So there are a number of people  who have a lot more "uh-oh" moments than others,  and among the worst are recent graduates of business school.
zh_test: 有那么一些人 他们的“糟了”时刻比其他人多 其中最糟的是新毕业的商学院学生
M2M100: 因此,有很多人比其他人有更多的“uh-oh”时刻,最糟糕的是最近的商学院毕业生。

en_test: They lie, they cheat, they get distracted  and they produce really lame structures.
zh_test: 他们说谎，他们欺骗，很容易受干扰 他们的建筑构造非常蹩脚
M2M100: 他们在说谎,他们在欺骗,他们被分散,他们产生真正的<unk>结构。

en_test: And of course there are teams  that have a lot more "ta-da" structures,  and among the best are recent graduates of kindergarten.
zh_test: 当然也有一些团队 他们创造了更多的“哈哈”时刻 其中最好的，就是新毕业的幼儿园小朋友
M2M100: 当然,有团队拥有更多的“ta-da”结构,其中最好的是幼儿园毕业生。

en_test: And it's pretty amazing.
zh_test: 这个真是很神奇
M2M100: 而且它是相当令人惊叹的。

en_test: As Peter tells us,  not only do they produce the tallest structures,  but they're the most interesting structures of them all.
zh_test: 正如PETER告诉我们的 他们不但造出了最高的建筑 而且他们搭建的结构也是最有趣的
M2M100: 正如彼得告诉我们,他们不仅生产了最高的结构,而且它们都是其中最有趣的结构。

en_test: So the question you want to ask is:  How come? Why? What is it about them?
zh_test: 所以你会问 这是怎么回事？他们到底有什么特点？
M2M100: 所以你想问的问题是:如何来?为什么?它是什么?

en_test: And Peter likes to say that  none of the kids spend any time  trying to be CEO of Spaghetti, Inc. Right?
zh_test: Peter喜欢这样说： “因为没有任何孩子企图做 意大利面条公司的总裁。” 是的
M2M100: 和彼得喜欢说,没有一个孩子花任何时间试图成为Spaghetti, Inc的首席执行官。

en_test: They don't spend time jockeying for power.
zh_test: 他们没在争夺权力上花任何时间
M2M100: 他们不花时间争取权力。

en_test: But there's another reason as well.
zh_test: 但是其中还有另一个原因
M2M100: 但是还有另一个原因。

en_test: And the reason is that business students are trained  to find the single right plan, right?
zh_test: 因为商学院的学生受过的专业训练是 去寻找一个正确的计划
M2M100: 而原因是,商業學生被訓練找到單一正確的計劃,不是嗎?

en_test: And then they execute on it.
zh_test: 然后他们按照计划执行
M2M100: 然後,他們將被執行。

en_test: And then what happens is, when they put the marshmallow on the top,  they run out of time and what happens?
zh_test: 然而事实是， 当他们把棉花糖放到顶部时 他们用完了有限的时间，然后呢
M2M100: 然后发生了什么事,当他们把火柴放在顶部时,他们会花时间,发生了什么事?

en_test: It's a crisis.
zh_test: 危机就降临了
M2M100: 这是一个危机。

en_test: Sound familiar? Right.
zh_test: 听着很熟悉吧？是的。
M2M100: 听起来很熟悉吗?

en_test: What kindergarteners do differently  is that they start with the marshmallow,  and they build prototypes, successive prototypes,  always keeping the marshmallow on top,  so they have multiple times to fix when they build prototypes along the way.
zh_test: 幼儿园的孩子的做法不一样 他们从棉花糖开始 他们先建一个样板模型， 然后不断在模型上加建， 其间总是让棉花糖保持在最上面 所以他们一直有很多机会去不断修正样板模型
M2M100: 幼儿园的不同的是,他们开始用火柴,他们建造原型,连续的原型,总是保持火柴在顶部,所以他们有几次修复,当他们建造原型在路上。

en_test: Designers recognize this type of collaboration  as the essence of the iterative process.
zh_test: 于是设计者认识到这种合作是 这个互动过程中的重要因素
M2M100: 设计师将这种类型的合作视为 iterative 过程的本质。

en_test: And with each version, kids get instant feedback  about what works and what doesn't work.
zh_test: 对每个版本，孩子都会迅速地得到反馈 他们知道什么行，什么不行
M2M100: 每個版本,孩子們都會得到關於什麼工作和什麼不工作的即時反馈。

en_test: So the capacity to play in prototype is really essential,  but let's look at how different teams perform.
zh_test: 所以把握雏形的能力是真正的关键 让我们来看看不同的队伍是怎样表现的
M2M100: 因此,在原型中发挥能力是非常重要的,但让我们看看不同的团队如何表现。

en_test: So the average for most people is around 20 inches;  business schools students, about half of that;  lawyers, a little better, but not much better than that,  kindergarteners, better than most adults.
zh_test: 大多数人建的塔的平均高度是20英尺 商学院学生， 大概是一半 律师好一些， 但也好不到哪里去 幼儿园的孩子，比大多数的成年人要好
M2M100: 因此,对于大多数人来说,平均值约为20英寸;商学院的学生,大约一半;律师,有点好,但不太好,幼儿园,比大多数成年人更好。

en_test: Who does the very best?
zh_test: 谁做得最好呢？
M2M100: 谁做得最好?

en_test: And why is it? Because they understand triangles  and self-reinforcing geometrical patterns  are the key to building  stable structures.

en_test: So CEOs, a little bit better than average,  but here's where it gets interesting.
zh_test: 总裁们比平均水平稍好一些 但是有趣的是
M2M100: 因此,首席执行官,比平均水平更好一点,但这就是它变得有趣的地方。

zh_test: 如果你在他们的小组里加一个行政助理 他们的成绩马上变得好很多

en_test: It's incredible. You know, you look around, you go, "Oh, that team's going to win."
zh_test: 这真是令人难以置信， 你四处看看， 你说：“那个小组会赢。”
M2M100: 你知道,你看着周围,你去,“哦,这个团队会赢。

en_test: You can just tell beforehand. And why is that?
zh_test: 你很早就知道， 为什么呢？
M2M100: 你可以提前说,为什么呢?

en_test: Because they have special skills  of facilitation.
zh_test: 因为他们有特殊的 简化技巧

en_test: I thought, let's up the ante, once.

M2M100: 因此,你可能會問:為什麼有人真的會花時間寫一張馬斯馬洛挑戰?

en_test: And the reason is, I help create  digital tools and processes  to help teams build cars and video games  and visual effects.

en_test: In other words, sugar pills  have a measurable effect in certain kinds of studies,  the placebo effect,  just because the person thinks  that what's happening to them is a pharmaceutical  or some sort of a --  for pain management, for example,  if they believe it enough there is a measurable effect in the body  called the placebo effect.

en_test: Anyone who doesn't distinguish those notions  is going to mess up the study of happiness,  and I belong to a crowd of students of well-being,  who've been messing up the study of happiness for a long time  in precisely this way.

M2M100: 任何不区分这些观念的人,都会把幸福的研究推开,我属于许多幸福的学生群体,他们已经把幸福的研究推开了很长一段时间,正是这样。

en_test: The distinction between the  happiness of the experiencing self  and the satisfaction of the remembering self  has been recognized in recent years,  and there are now efforts to measure the two separately.
zh_test: 近年来， 经验自我的快乐 和记忆自我的满足的 差异性已能分清， 目前正努力来分别测度两者，
M2M100: 在过去的几年里,体验自我的幸福与记忆自我的满意度之间的区别已被认可,现在正在努力分别测量两者。

en_test: The Gallup Organization has a world poll  where more than half a million people  have been asked questions  about what they think of their life  and about their experiences,  and there have been other efforts along those lines.
zh_test: 盖洛普公司最近在全世界举行了一场民意调查， 其中逾五十万人 都被问及一个类似的问题， 那就是他们如何看待他们的生活 和如何看待他们的经验。 除了这个问题，这个公司还做了其它的调查。
M2M100: Gallup 有一个世界调查,其中超过半百万人被问及他们对自己的生活和经验的看法,并在这些线上进行了其他努力。

en_test: So in recent years, we have begun to learn  about the happiness of the two selves.
zh_test: 近年来，我们逐渐得知 关于两种快乐见解的信息。
M2M100: 因此,近年来,我们已经开始了解两个人幸福。

en_test: And the main lesson I think that we have learned  is they are really different.
zh_test: 我认为我们主要学到的便是 两者是天壤之别的。
M2M100: 我认为我们学到的主要教训是,他们真的不同。

en_test: You can know how satisfied somebody is with their life,  and that really doesn't teach you much  about how happily they're living their life,  and vice versa.
zh_test: 虽然你可以得知一个人对生活是否满意， 但却无法告诉你 他们平常活的有多快乐， 而反之亦然。
M2M100: 你可以知道有人对自己的生活有多满意,这真的不教你很多关于他们生活有多幸福,反之亦然。

en_test: Just to give you a sense of the correlation,  the correlation is about .5.
zh_test: 只是为了让你对其中的关联性有个基本概念， 它们之间大概只有50%关联。
M2M100: 要让你感觉到相似之处,相似之处是5。

en_test: What that means is if you met somebody,  and you were told, "Oh his father is six feet tall,"  how much would you know about his height?
zh_test: 意思是当你见到某个人时， 你被告知他的爸爸有六尺高， 你能知道这个人有多高么？
M2M100: 如果你遇到一个人,你被告知“他的父亲高六英尺”,你会知道他的身高多少?

en_test: Well, you would know something about his height,  but there's a lot of uncertainty.
zh_test: 好吧，你可能有个基本概念， 但非常不确定。
M2M100: 好吧,你会知道他的高度,但有很多不确定性。

en_test: You have that much uncertainty.
zh_test: 你无法下判定。
M2M100: 你有这么多不确定性。

en_test: If I tell you that somebody ranked their life eight on a scale of ten,  you have a lot of uncertainty  about how happy they are  with their experiencing self.
zh_test: 若我说有人给自己的生活质量打分，他打8/10分， 你也不能把握 他们的经验自我 有多么快乐。
M2M100: 如果我告诉你,有人把他们的生活分为八个,在十个规模上,你有很多不确定性,他们是多么幸福与他们的经历自我。

en_test: So the correlation is low.
zh_test: 所以关联性很低。
M2M100: 因此,相互关系很低。

en_test: We know something about what controls  satisfaction of the happiness self.
zh_test: 我们知道什么能够 让人的快乐得到满足。
M2M100: 我们知道什么控制了幸福的自我满意度。

en_test: We know that money is very important,  goals are very important.
zh_test: 我们知道钱是很重要的， 目标也非常重要。
M2M100: 我们知道金钱很重要,目标很重要。

en_test: We know that happiness is mainly  being satisfied with people that we like,  spending time with people that we like.
zh_test: 我们知道要快乐是需要通过 我们所喜爱的人来满足， 是需要花时间和他们待在一起来满足。
M2M100: 我们知道,幸福主要是满足我们喜欢的人,花时间与我们喜欢的人。

en_test: There are other pleasures, but this is dominant.
zh_test: 虽然还有其它因素，但这是主要因素。
M2M100: 还有其他乐趣,但这一点是主导的。

en_test: So if you want to maximize the happiness of the two selves,  you are going to end up  doing very different things.
zh_test: 所以假若你想让两个自我都快乐， 你必须抛弃旧习 且要做些与众不同的事。
M2M100: 所以,如果你想最大限度地提高两个人幸福,你最终会做非常不同的事情。

en_test: The bottom line of what I've said here  is that we really should not think of happiness  as a substitute for well-being.
zh_test: 我说的是，我们至少 不应把快乐当成活得好的 代名词。
M2M100: 我在这里所说的底线是,我们真的不应该认为幸福是福利的替代品。

en_test: It is a completely different notion.
zh_test: 这两者是天壤之别的。
M2M100: 这是一个完全不同的概念。

en_test: Now, very quickly,  another reason we cannot think straight about happiness  is that we do not attend to the same things  when we think about life, and we actually live.
zh_test: 现在，很快地讨论下 另一个我们不能理解快乐本质的原因， 那就是我们怎么看生活 和我们怎么过生活是不一样的。
M2M100: 现在,很快,我们无法直接思考幸福的另一个原因是,当我们思考生命时,我们不参加相同的事情,而实际上我们生活。

en_test: So, if you ask the simple question of how happy people are in California,  you are not going to get to the correct answer.
zh_test: 所以，当你问加州的人有多快乐时， 你将无法得到正确答案。
M2M100: 所以,如果你问一个简单的问题是加利福尼亚人是多么幸福,你不会得到正确的答案。

en_test: When you ask that question,  you think people must be happier in California  if, say, you live in Ohio.
zh_test: 因为当你这样问时， 你认为加州人一定过得比较快乐， 而你则住在俄亥俄州。
M2M100: 当你问这个问题时,你认为人们应该在加利福尼亚更快乐,如果你说,你住在俄亥俄州。

en_test: And what happens is  when you think about living in California,  you are thinking of the contrast  between California and other places,  and that contrast, say, is in climate.
zh_test: 当你在想 住在加州有多快乐时， 你会想到加州和其他州域 之间的差异性， 譬如，气候。
M2M100: 而发生的事情就是当你想到生活在加利福尼亚时,你正在思考加利福尼亚和其他地方之间的对比,而这种对比,说,在气候中。

en_test: Well, it turns out that climate  is not very important to the experiencing self  and it's not even very important to the reflective self  that decides how happy people are.
zh_test: 事实证明气候条件 对于经验自我并非很重要 而且对于思考自我 衡量自己有多快乐也不太重要。
M2M100: 好吧,显然,气候对经历的自我并不太重要,对于决定幸福的人的反射自我也不太重要。

en_test: But now, because the reflective self is in charge,  you may end up -- some people may end up  moving to California.
zh_test: 不过，既然现实由思考自我主导， 一些人可能会得到这样一种结论， 那就是搬到加州。
M2M100: 但是现在,因为反射的自我负责,你可能会结束 - 有些人可能会结束移动到加利福尼亚。

en_test: And it's sort of interesting to trace what is going to happen  to people who move to California in the hope of getting happier.
zh_test: 他们搬去加州是为了过上更快乐的生活， 是而追踪观看他们的后续发展，将会是一件相当有趣的事。
M2M100: 而且有趣的是跟踪会发生什么的人搬到加利福尼亚,希望变得更快乐。

en_test: Well, their experiencing self  is not going to get happier.
zh_test: 他们的经验自我 是不会变得更快乐。
M2M100: 好吧,他们的体验自我不会变得更快乐。

en_test: We know that.
zh_test: 这我们都知道。
M2M100: 我们知道这一点。

en_test: But one thing will happen: They will think they are happier,  because, when they think about it,  they'll be reminded of how horrible the weather was in Ohio,  and they will feel they made the right decision.
zh_test: 不过当一件事发生后，他们会觉得自己快乐多了。 因为在他们思考时， 他们会回想起俄亥俄州的坏天气。 他们也因此觉得他们做出了正确的决定。
M2M100: 但有一件事会发生:他们会认为自己更快乐,因为当他们想到的时候,他们会记得俄亥俄州的天气是多么可怕,他们会觉得自己做出了正确的决定。

en_test: to think straight about well-being,  and I hope I have given you a sense  of how difficult it is.
zh_test: 要理解快乐生活 实在很难， 我希望我已经让你们对此有个基本概念， 并且明白这个过程到底有多难。

en_test: Thank you.

en_test: Now, when we were on the phone a few weeks ago,  you mentioned to me that there was quite an interesting result  came out of that Gallup survey.

M2M100: 现在,当我们在几周前打电话时,你告诉我,从那个Gallup调查中得到了相当有趣的结果。

zh_test: 请问您可以跟我们分享一下吗？ 我们还有几分钟的时间。
M2M100: 这是你可以分享的,因为你现在留下了一些时刻吗?

zh_test: 丹尼尔·卡纳曼：没问题。

en_test: I think the most interesting result that we found in the Gallup survey  is a number, which we absolutely did not expect to find.

M2M100: 我认为我们在Gallup调查中发现的最有趣的结果是一个数字,我们绝对不期望找到。

en_test: We found that with respect to the happiness  of the experiencing self.
zh_test: 我们发现一个关于 经验自我的快乐的现象。
M2M100: 我们发现这一点与经历的自我的幸福有关。

en_test: When we looked at how feelings,  vary with income.
zh_test: 那就是人的感觉 会随收入的多少而变化。
M2M100: 当我们看到情绪如何时,与收入不同。

en_test: And it turns out that, below an income  of 60,000 dollars a year, for Americans --  and that's a very large sample of Americans, like 600,000,  so it's a large representative sample --  below an income of 600,000 dollars a year...
zh_test: 结果表明，对于年收入低于六万美元的 美国人而言， 这占了样本中的很大一部分， 将近有六十万人，这些人是相当具有指标性的， 这些年收入低于六十万美元......
M2M100: 事实证明,美国人每年收入低于6万美元,美国人每年收入低于6万美元,美国人每年收入低于6万美元,美国人每年收入低于6万美元,美国人每年收入低于6万美元。

zh_test: 安德森：是六万美元。
卡纳曼：六万美元。
M2M100: DK:60万。

en_test: 60,000 dollars a year, people are unhappy,  and they get progressively unhappier the poorer they get.
zh_test: 年收入六万美元的人是不快乐的， 而且收入越低，他们则逾不快乐。
M2M100: 每年6万美元,人们不快乐,他们逐渐变得不快乐,他们得到了最贫穷的。

en_test: Above that, we get an absolutely flat line.

M2M100: 超越这一点,我们得到了一个绝对平坦的线条。

en_test: I mean I've rarely seen lines so flat.

M2M100: 我想我很少看到线路如此平坦。

en_test: Clearly, what is happening is  money does not buy you experiential happiness,  but lack of money certainly buys you misery,  and we can measure that misery  very, very clearly.
zh_test: 显然 金钱是无法买到经验自我的快乐， 但没钱却的确能给你带来悲郁的境况， 而且我们清楚地测到痛苦的程度， 非常清楚。
M2M100: 显然,正在发生的事情是,金钱不会为你买体验幸福,但缺乏金钱可能会为你买悲伤,我们可以非常,非常清楚地测量这种悲伤。

en_test: In terms of the other self, the remembering self,  you get a different story.
zh_test: 对于另一个自我，记忆自我而言。 你则有了一个大相迳庭的故事。
M2M100: 至于另一个自我,记住的自我,你得到一个不同的故事。

en_test: The more money you earn, the more satisfied you are.
zh_test: 你赚的越多，你就越满意。

zh_test: 安德森：可是丹尼，生命、自由和追求快乐 是所有美国人奋斗的目标。
M2M100: 但是,丹尼,整个美国的努力是关于生活,自由,追求幸福。

en_test: If people took seriously that finding,  I mean, it seems to turn upside down  everything we believe about, like for example,  taxation policy and so forth.
zh_test: 假若大家都认真对待这一发现， 那么，这将颠覆我们 固有的观念，例如， 课税政策等。

en_test: Is there any chance that politicians, that the country generally,  would take a finding like that seriously  and run public policy based on it?
zh_test: 这个国家的政治人物有没有可能 会正视这样的发现 并且依次施政？
M2M100: 有没有机会,政治家,这个国家一般,会认真对待这样的发现,并以此为基础的公共政策?

en_test: DK: You know I think that there is recognition  of the role of happiness research in public policy.
zh_test: 卡纳曼：我认为已有人认知到研究快乐 于谋划政策中的地位。
M2M100: DK:你知道,我认为在公共政策中认识到幸福研究的作用。

en_test: The recognition is going to be slow in the United States,  no question about that,  but in the U.K., it is happening,  and in other countries it is happening.
zh_test: 但这项认知于美国的传播速度颇慢， 这是毋庸置疑的， 但在英国，它正持续发酵， 其他国家亦然。
M2M100: 承认将在美国缓慢,没有问题,但在英国,它正在发生,在其他国家,它正在发生。

en_test: People are recognizing that they ought  to be thinking of happiness  when they think of public policy.

M2M100: 人们认识到,当他们思考公共政策时,他们应该思考幸福。

en_test: It's going to take a while,  and people are going to debate  whether they want to study experience happiness,  or whether they want to study life evaluation,  so we need to have that debate fairly soon.
zh_test: 虽然这将花些时间， 但人们也将开始思考。 他们要的是经验的快乐 抑或是为生活打分， 因此很快，我们将要理解这个问题。

en_test: How to enhance happiness  goes very different ways depending on how you think,  and whether you think of the remembering self  or you think of the experiencing self.

en_test: This is going to influence policy, I think, in years to come.

en_test: This is going to be, I think, within the next decade or two,  part of national statistics.

en_test: CA: Well, it seems to me that this issue will -- or at least should be --  the most interesting policy discussion to track over the next few years.
zh_test: 安德森：这个议题对于我来说 将会是未来几年里 最有的一个政策讨论议题。

en_test: What happened was women, for example,  who wanted the right to vote,  took the Founding Fathers' concept  of anatomical commonality being more important  than anatomical difference  and said, "The fact that we have a uterus and ovaries  is not significant enough in terms of a difference  to mean that we shouldn't have the right to vote,  the right to full citizenship,  the right to own property, etc., etc."

en_test: So what does this mean,  as we look back at what has happened in evolution,  and as we think about the place again  of humans in evolution,  and particularly as we look ahead  to the next phase,  I would say  that there are a number of possibilities.
zh_test: 所以，这意味着什么， 当我们回头看进化过程中发生的事情， 以及我们再想想 进化中的人类， 特别是我们向上看 到下一个阶段的时候 我只能说 有很多的可能性。

en_test: The first is that we will not evolve.
zh_test: 第一种可能，我们不会进化了。
M2M100: 首先,我们不会进化。

en_test: We have reached  a kind of equipoise.

en_test: And the reasoning behind that would be,  first, we have, through medicine,  managed to preserve a lot of genes  that would otherwise be selected out  and be removed from the population.

M2M100: 而背后的理性是,首先,我们通过医学,能够保存很多基因,否则将被选出并从人口中移除。

en_test: And secondly, we as a species  have so configured our environment  that we have managed to make it adapt to us  as well as we adapt to it.

en_test: And by the way, we immigrate and circulate  and intermix so much  that you can't any longer  have the isolation that is necessary  for evolution to take place.
zh_test: 另外，我们移民，流通 而且混杂在一起 这使得你不在 处于隔离状态，而这个状态又正是 进化发生的必要条件。

en_test: A second possibility  is that there will be evolution of the traditional kind,  natural, imposed by the forces of nature.

en_test: And the argument here would be  that the wheels of evolution grind slowly,  but they are inexorable.

en_test: And as far as isolation goes,  when we as a species  do colonize distant planets,  there will be the isolation and the environmental changes  that could produce evolution  in the natural way.
zh_test: 只有孤立现象存在， 而我们作为一个物种 统治着遥远的星球 那就会有孤立的现象，环境的改变 会导致的进化 自然界方式的进化。
M2M100: 至于隔离,当我们作为物种殖民遥远的行星时,将会有隔离和环境变化,以自然方式产生进化。

en_test: But there's a third possibility,  an enticing, intriguing and frightening possibility.

en_test: I call it neo-evolution --  the new evolution  that is not simply natural,  but guided and chosen  by us as individuals  in the choices that we will make.

We choose not to choose,  even when it goes against our best self-interests.

en_test: Under the Taliban, girls who went to school  numbered in the hundreds --  remember, it was illegal.

en_test: I led an initiative by the Libyan Women's Platform for Peace  to lobby for a more inclusive electoral law,  a law that would give every citizen, no matter what your background,  the right to vote and run,  and most importantly to stipulate on political parties  the alternation of male and female candidates vertically and horizontally in their lists,  creating the zipper list.

en_test: In Hindu mythology, Jatayu was the vulture god,  and he risked his life in order to save the goddess Sita  from the 10-headed demon Ravana.
zh_test: 在印度教神话中，秃鹫之神名为雅达尤， 他冒着生命危险 从10头恶魔罗波那手中救出了西妲女神。

en_test: In Tibetan culture, they are performing very important  sky burials. In places like Tibet, there are no places  to bury the dead, or wood to cremate them,  so these vultures provide a natural disposal system.
zh_test: 在西藏文化中，秃鹫尤其显得重要 天葬。在那些类似西藏的地方，既没有条件 土葬，也没有木材去进行火葬， 所以秃鹫为当地人提供了一种天然的尸体处理系统。
M2M100: 在西藏等地方,没有地方可以埋葬死人,或者树木可以挖掘他们,所以这些树木提供了一个自然排放系统。

en_test: So what is the problem with vultures?
zh_test: 那么秃鹫都面临着哪些问题呢？
M2M100: 那么,什么是泡沫问题呢?

en_test: We have eight species of vultures that occur in Kenya,  of which six are highly threatened with extinction.
zh_test: 肯尼亚生长着八种秃鹫， 其中的六种正濒临灭绝。
M2M100: 肯尼亚有8种种种,其中6种受到灭绝威胁。

en_test: The reason is that they're getting poisoned, and the reason  that they're getting poisoned is because there's  human-wildlife conflicts. The pastoral communities  are using this poison to target predators,  and in return, the vultures are falling victim to this.
zh_test: 很多秃鹫被毒死，中毒的原因 是因为在肯尼亚正在发生的 人类与野生动物之间对于生存空间的争夺。牧人们 使用毒药来对付掠食动物， 掠食动物被毒死之后，秃鹫们随之成为了下一个受害者。
M2M100: 原因是他们被中毒,原因是他们被中毒是因为人与野生动物的冲突。牧师社区正在使用这种中毒来针对掠夺者,相反,<unk>虫正在成为这一事件的受害者。

en_test: In South Asia, in countries like India and Pakistan,  four species of vultures are listed as critically endangered,  which means they have less than 10 or 15 years to go extinct,  and the reason is because they are falling prey  by consuming livestock that has been treated  with a painkilling drug like Diclofenac.
zh_test: 在南亚，一些国家类似于印度和巴基斯坦， 四种秃鹫被列为极度濒临灭绝中， 这意味着在他们将会在10到15年之内彻底灭绝， 灭绝的原因是因为秃鹫们 食用了那些生前曾被喂食过 含有双氯芬酸成分止疼药的家畜。
M2M100: 在南亚,印度和巴基斯坦等国家,有四种牲畜被列为危险的,这意味着它们不到10年或15年才能灭绝,原因是因为它们因食用已用一种缓解疼痛的药物(如Diclofenac)治疗的牲畜而陷入困境。

en_test: This drug has now been banned for veterinary use in India,  and they have taken a stand.
zh_test: 现在含有双氯芬酸的兽药已经被禁止在印度使用， 印度政府表现出了积极的态度。
M2M100: 这种药物现在已被禁止用于印度的兽医用途,他们已经采取了立场。

en_test: Because there are no vultures, there's been a spread  in the numbers of feral dogs at carcass dump sites,  and when you have feral dogs, you have a huge time bomb  of rabies. The number of cases of rabies  has increased tremendously in India.
zh_test: 因为秃鹫数量的骤减，野狗开始 在牲畜尸体掩埋场周围泛滥成灾， 在野狗泛滥的地区，狂犬病就像定时炸弹一样 随时都会爆发。狂犬病案例的数量 在印度出现了惊人的增长。
M2M100: 因为没有<unk>子,在<unk>子跳动场所的<unk>子狗的数量已经蔓延,当你有<unk>子狗时,你有一个巨大的时间炸弹的愤怒。

en_test: Kenya is going to have one of the largest wind farms in Africa:  353 wind turbines are going to be up at Lake Turkana.
zh_test: 肯尼亚即将拥有全非洲最大规模的风力发电厂： 353台涡轮发电机即将被安装在图尔卡纳湖区。

en_test: I am not against wind energy, but we need to work  with the governments, because wind turbines  do this to birds. They slice them in half.
zh_test: 我不反对开发风能，但是我们应该呼吁 政府重新考虑这项决定，因为风力涡轮机 会对鸟类造成威胁。高速的扇叶会把鸟儿“切”成两半。
M2M100: 我不是反对风能,但我们需要与政府合作,因为风力涡轮机对鸟类这样做。

en_test: They are bird-blending machines.

en_test: In West Africa, there's a horrific trade  of dead vultures to serve the witchcraft and the fetish market.

en_test: So what's being done? Well, we're conducting research  on these birds. We're putting transmitters on them.

en_test: We're trying to determine their basic ecology,  and see where they go.
zh_test: 我们试图去查明秃鹫与周围环境的关系 并且了解秃鹫的行踪。

en_test: We can see that they travel different countries, so  if you focus on a problem locally, it's not going to help you.

en_test: We're talking to them about appreciating vultures,  about the need from within to appreciate these  wonderful creatures and the services that they provide.
zh_test: 我们正在尽力让他们了解到秃鹫的益处， 并且发自内心得去感激这些 奇妙的生物和他们为自然所做的贡献。

en_test: How can you help? You can become active,  make noise. You can write a letter to your government  and tell them that we need to focus on these very  misunderstood creatures. Volunteer your time  to spread the word. Spread the word.

en_test: When you walk out of this room, you will be informed  about vultures, but speak to your families, to your children,  to your neighbors about vultures.
zh_test: 当你走出这个房间的时候，你们就是 秃鹫达人了，不但要告诉你的家人们，还要 告诉你们的邻居们有关秃鹫的故事。

en_test: They are very graceful. Charles Darwin said  he changed his mind because he watched them fly  effortlessly without energy in the skies.
zh_test: 它们是那么的优雅。查尔斯 达尔文曾说到 他改变了自己的看法，在他看到秃鹫们在空中 优雅而又浑然天成的身姿之后。

en_test: Kenya, this world, will be much poorer  without these wonderful species.

en_test: Everything I do, and everything I do professionally --  my life -- has been shaped  by seven years of work as a young man in Africa.
zh_test: 我所做的一切，不论是生活上还是工作上 我的整个人生--深深受到 年轻时在非洲工作的那七年的影响，
M2M100: 我所做的一切,我所做的一切,我所做的一切,我的生活,都是由七年的非洲青年工作所塑造的。

en_test: From 1971 to 1977 --  I look young, but I'm not —  --  I worked in Zambia, Kenya, Ivory Coast, Algeria, Somalia,  in projects of technical cooperation with African countries.
zh_test: 从1971年到1977年。 我看起来很年轻，但其实我老了-- 我曾在赞比亚，肯尼亚，象牙海岸，阿尔及利亚，索马里 参与过不少与非洲各国的技术合作项目。

en_test: I worked for an Italian NGO,  and every single project that we set up in Africa  failed.

en_test: I thought, age 21, that we Italians were good people  and we were doing good work in Africa.

en_test: Instead, everything we touched we killed.

en_test: Our first project, the one that has inspired my first book,  "Ripples from the Zambezi,"  was a project where we Italians  decided to teach Zambian people how to grow food.
zh_test: 我们第一个项目给了我写第一本书的灵感， 书名叫《赞比西河的涟漪》。 在这个项目中，我们意大利人 决定教赞比亚人种粮食。

en_test: So we arrived there with Italian seeds in southern Zambia  in this absolutely magnificent valley  going down to the Zambezi River,  and we taught the local people how to grow Italian tomatoes  and zucchini and ...
zh_test: 所以，我们带着意大利的种子来到了赞比亚南部， 一个壮丽迷人的山谷， 通向赞比西河。 我们教当地人种植意大利西红柿 和西葫芦等等。

en_test: And of course the local people had absolutely no interest  in doing that, so we paid them to come and work,  and sometimes they would show up.   And we were amazed that the local people, in such a fertile valley, would not have any agriculture.

en_test: But instead of asking them how come they were not  growing anything, we simply said, "Thank God we're here."   "Just in the nick of time to save the Zambian people from starvation."
zh_test: 我们对此感到十分惊奇。 但我们并没有问他们原因， 而仅仅是感叹道：“幸亏我们来了。” “在饥饿的赞比亚人民命悬一线时伸出了援手。”

en_test: And of course, everything in Africa grew beautifully.

en_test: We had these magnificent tomatoes. In Italy, a tomato  would grow to this size. In Zambia, to this size.
zh_test: 我们种的西红柿漂亮极了。在意大利，一个西红柿 长这么大。在赞比亚，能长这么大。

en_test: And the Zambians said, "Yes, that's why we have no agriculture here."   "Why didn't you tell us?""You never asked."

en_test: I thought it was only us Italians blundering around Africa,  but then I saw what the Americans were doing,  what the English were doing, what the French were doing,  and after seeing what they were doing,  I became quite proud of our project in Zambia.
zh_test: 我本以为只有我们意大利人在非洲栽了跟头， 但当我知道美国人的情况， 英国人的情况，法国人的情况， 当看了他们的所作所为之后， 我为我们在赞比亚的项目感到非常自豪。

en_test: But they mean two different things.

en_test: Paternalistic, I treat anybody from a different culture  as if they were my children. "I love you so much."

en_test: Patronizing, I treat everybody from another culture  as if they were my servants.

en_test: I was given a slap in the face reading a book,  "Small is Beautiful," written by Schumacher, who said,  above all in economic development, if people  do not wish to be helped, leave them alone.

M2M100: 这些人根本没有逃避,因为我们在这样一个艰难的问题上,重要的是要注意,奴隶制,包括性贩运,也发生在我们自己的背景下。

en_test: Tens of hundreds of people are enslaved in agriculture,  in restaurants, in domestic servitude,  and the list can go on.
zh_test: 几千人成为农奴 餐馆奴工、家庭奴工 还不止这些
M2M100: 数以百计的人在农业、餐馆、家庭服务中被奴役,这份名单可以继续下去。

en_test: Recently, the New York Times reported that  between 100,000 and 300,000 American children  are sold into sex slavery every year.
zh_test: 最近，纽约时报报道 美国每年有10万到30万小孩 被买卖成为性奴
M2M100: 据《纽约时报》报道,每年有10万至30万名美国儿童被卖成性奴隶制。

en_test: It's all around us. We just don't see it.
zh_test: 这些事就发生在我们身边，我们只是不知道罢了
M2M100: 它是我们周围的,我们只是看不见它。

en_test: The textile industry is another one we often think of  when we hear about slave labor.
zh_test: 纺织业 也是我们听到奴役劳动时经常联想到的
M2M100: 纺织行业是我们经常听到关于奴隶劳动的另一个问题。

en_test: I visited villages in India where entire families were enslaved  in the silk trade.
zh_test: 我在印度拜访过一个村子 全家人都是丝绸贸易的奴隶
M2M100: 我访问了印度的村庄,在那里整个家庭在丝绸贸易中被奴役。

en_test: This is a family portrait.
zh_test: 这是一家人的“肖像”
M2M100: 这是一个家庭肖像。

en_test: The dyed black hands are the father, while the blue  and red hands are his sons.
zh_test: 那双被染黑了的手属于这家的父亲 蓝色和红色的手属于两个儿子
M2M100: 黑手是父亲,蓝手和红手是他的儿子。

en_test: They mix dye in these big barrels,  and they submerge the silk into the liquid up to their elbows,  but the dye is toxic.
zh_test: 他们在大桶里搅拌燃料 然后把丝绸深深地浸进去，直到染料淹到手肘 这些染料都是有毒的
M2M100: 他们将泥土混合在这些大桶里,他们将泥土浸入液体,直到他们的尾巴,但泥土是有毒的。

en_test: My interpreter told me their stories.
zh_test: 翻译告诉我他们的故事
M2M100: 我的翻译员告诉我他们的故事。

en_test: "We have no freedom," they said.
zh_test: “我们没有自由”，他们说道
M2M100: “我们没有自由,”他们说。

en_test: "We hope still, though, that we could leave this house  someday and go someplace else  where we actually get paid for our dyeing."
zh_test: “可我们还是希望，哪天可以逃离这个屋子 去其他的地方 在那里工作能拿到报酬”
M2M100: “然而,我们仍然希望有一天我们能离开这个房子,去别的地方,我们实际上会为我们的装饰付出代价。

en_test: It's estimated that more than 4,000 children  are enslaved on Lake Volta,  the largest man-made lake in the world.
zh_test: 据估计，有超过4000名儿童 在沃尔特湖水库被奴役 那里是世界上最大的人工湖
M2M100: 据估计,有4000多名儿童在伏尔塔湖被奴役,这是世界上最大的人造湖泊。

en_test: When we first arrived, I went to have a quick look.
zh_test: 我们一到那里，我就去看了个大概
M2M100: 当我们第一次到达时,我得到了快速的眼光。

en_test: I saw what seemed to be a family fishing on a boat,  two older brothers, some younger kids, makes sense right?
zh_test: 我看到似乎是一家人在船上捕鱼 两个哥哥，几个小点的孩子，挺像的吧？
M2M100: 我看到一艘船上看起来像是家庭钓鱼,两个年长的兄弟,一些年轻的孩子,有什么意义?

en_test: Wrong. They were all enslaved.
zh_test: 错！他们都是奴隶
M2M100: 错了,他们都是奴隶。

en_test: Children are taken from their families  and trafficked and vanished,  and they're forced to work endless hours on these boats  on the lake, even though they do not know how to swim.
zh_test: 孩子们从家里被带出来 被贩卖 被迫在船上无休止的工作 他们在湖上工作，甚至还不会游泳
M2M100: 孩子们被家人带走,被贩卖和消失,他们被迫在湖边的这些船上无止境工作,尽管他们不知道如何游泳。

en_test: This young child is eight years old.
zh_test: 这个小男孩8岁大
M2M100: 这个小男孩已经八岁了。

en_test: He was trembling when our boat approached,  frightened it would run over his tiny canoe.
zh_test: 当我们的船靠近的时候 他在发抖 他怕我们的船会撞上上他的独木舟
M2M100: 當我們的船接近時,他震動了,害怕它會在他的小峡谷上奔跑。

en_test: He was petrified he would be knocked in the water.
zh_test: 他很害怕会掉到水里
M2M100: 他被打死了,他会被打在水里。

en_test: The skeletal tree limbs submerged in Lake Volta  often catch the fishing nets, and weary,  frightened children are thrown into the water  to untether the lines.
zh_test: 湖面下浸着些树的枝干 经常会挂住渔网 这些疲惫、害怕的孩子们就被扔到水中 去解开渔网
M2M100: 沉浸在伏尔塔湖的骨骼树膜经常捕捉捕鱼网,疲惫而害怕的孩子们被扔进水里,以消灭线路。

en_test: Many of them drown.
zh_test: 很多人都淹死了
M2M100: 很多人都沉没了。

en_test: For as long as he can recall, he's been forced to work  on the lake.
zh_test: 从他记事开始， 就被迫在湖上工作
M2M100: 因为只要他能记得,他就被迫在湖上工作。

en_test: Terrified of his master, he will not run away,  and since he's been treated with cruelty all his life,  he passes that down to the younger slaves  I met these boys at five in the morning,  when they were hauling in the last of their nets,  but they had been working since 1 a.m.
zh_test: 他非常害怕主人，不敢逃跑 由于他从小就被残酷对待 他也用同样的方法 对待比他小的奴隶 我在早上五点时看到这些男孩子们 在收最后一个渔网 可他们从凌晨1点就开始工作了
M2M100: 害怕他的主人,他不会逃跑,因为他一生都被残酷的待遇,他传达到年轻的奴隶我遇到了这些男孩五点早上,当他们在他们的最后的网,但他们从早上1点开始工作。

en_test: in the cold, windy night.
zh_test: 在这样寒冷，刮风的晚上
M2M100: 在寒冷的夜晚。

en_test: And it's important to note that these nets weigh  more than a thousand pounds when they're full of fish.
zh_test: 要知道这些渔网装满鱼的时候 重量有上千斤啊！
M2M100: 而且重要的是要注意,这些网体重超过一千英镑,当它们充满鱼类时。

en_test: I want to introduce you to Kofi.
zh_test: 我要介绍你们认识Kofi
M2M100: 我想把你介绍给科菲。

en_test: Kofi was rescued from a fishing village.
zh_test: 他从一个渔村被解救出来
M2M100: 科菲被救出一个渔村。

en_test: I met him at a shelter where Free the Slaves  rehabilitates victims of slavery. Here he's seen taking a bath at the well,  pouring big buckets of water over his head,  and the wonderful news is,  as you and I are sitting here talking today,  Kofi has been reunited with his family,  and what's even better, his family has been given tools  to make a living and to keep their children safe.
zh_test: 见到他是在一个收容所里 Free the Slaves组织用于复元奴役受害者的一个地方 照片上他正在井边洗澡 把一桶桶水往头上倒 好消息是 此时此刻 Kofi 已经和家人团聚了 更让人欣喜的是，他们一家已能够自己谋生 并确保孩子们的安全
M2M100: 我遇到了他在一个避难所,在那里自由的奴隶恢复了奴隶制的受害者,在这里他被看到在水井里洗澡,在他的头上流出大量的水,而奇妙的消息是,当你和我今天坐在这里谈话时,科菲已经与他的家人聚集在一起,更重要的是,他的家人被赋予了工具,以便让他们的孩子生活和保持安全。

en_test: Kofi is the embodiment of possibility.
zh_test: Kofi 身上体现了一种可能性
M2M100: 科菲是可能性的体现。

en_test: Who will he become because someone took a stand  and made a difference in his life?
zh_test: 正因为有人表明了立场，影响了他的人生 他的未来才可能有所改变
M2M100: 他会成为谁,因为有人站立并在他的生活中做出差异?

en_test: Driving down a road in Ghana  with partners of Free the Slaves,  a fellow abolitionist on a moped suddenly sped up  to our cruiser and tapped on the window.
zh_test: 开车行驶在加纳的一条路上 与Free the Slaves的伙伴一起 一个骑着电单车的同行人突然加速 靠近我们的车，敲着车窗
M2M100: 在加纳的一条路上与自由奴隶的合作伙伴一起开车,一辆摩托车上的同事突然向我们的巡航员开车,并在窗户上碰撞。

en_test: He told us to follow him down a dirt road into the jungle.
zh_test: 他让我们跟他改走一条土路通向丛林
M2M100: 他告诉我们要跟着他一条干燥的道路进入丛林。

en_test: At the end of the road, he urged us out of the car,  and told the driver to quickly leave.
zh_test: 在路的尽头，他催促我们下车 让司机赶紧走
M2M100: 路程结束时,他敦促我们离开车,并告诉司机快点离开。

en_test: Then he pointed toward this barely visible footpath,  and said, "This is the path, this is the path. Go."
zh_test: 然后他指着地上一排很不明显的脚印说 “就是这里，就是这条路。走！”
M2M100: 然後,他指向這幾乎可見的腳步,並說:「這就是道路,這就是道路。

en_test: As we started down the path, we pushed aside the vines  blocking the way, and after about an hour of walking in,  found that the trail had become flooded by recent rains,  so I hoisted the photo gear above my head  After another two hours of hiking, the winding trail  abruptly ended at a clearing, and before us  was a mass of holes  that could fit into the size of a football field,
zh_test: 我们拨开挡路的藤蔓 徒步走了约一个小时 小径被近期的雨水淹没了 我把拍摄器材举过头顶 趟着齐胸口深的水继续走 又走了两个小时 蜿蜒的小径戛然而止 我们面前的空地上出现了一大片坑洞
M2M100: 当我们开始走路时,我们把阻止道路的葡萄酒推到另一边,经过大约一个小时的步行后,发现路线被最近的雨水淹没了,所以我把照片装置放在我的头顶上,经过两小时的步行后,风向路线突然结束了清理,在我们之前,有大量的洞可以匹配足球场的尺寸。

en_test: and all of them were full of enslaved people laboring.
zh_test: 每个都有一个橄榄球场那么大
M2M100: 他们都充满了奴隶劳动的人。

en_test: Many women had children strapped to their backs  while they were panning for gold,  wading in water poisoned by mercury.
zh_test: 每个坑洞里都有奴隶在工作 很多妇女还背着自己的小孩 他们在淘金 在被汞污染的脏水里行走
M2M100: 许多妇女在为黄金而跳舞时,把孩子们拉到背上,沉浸在水中,被水泥中毒。

en_test: Mercury is used in the extraction process.
zh_test: 汞是用来提取金子的
M2M100: 水星在提取过程中使用。

en_test: These miners are enslaved in a mine shaft  in another part of Ghana.
zh_test: 这些人被奴役 在加纳的另一处矿井里
M2M100: 这些矿工在加纳另一个地区的矿井里被奴役。

en_test: When they came out of the shaft, they were soaking wet  from their own sweat.
zh_test: 当她们走出矿井时 全身汗湿
M2M100: 當他們從門口出來時,他們從自己的汗水中潮湿。

en_test: I remember looking into their tired, bloodshot eyes,  for many of them had been underground for 72 hours.
zh_test: 我记得他们布满红血丝的眼睛里充满疲惫 其中很多人已在井下工作72个小时
M2M100: 我记得看着他们疲惫的血腥的眼睛,因为他们中的许多人已经在地下72小时。

en_test: The shafts are up to 300 feet deep, and they carry out  heavy bags of stone that later will be transported  to another area, where the stone will be pounded  so that they can extract the gold.
zh_test: 这些井有差不多有90多米深 他们抬出来装满重石的袋子 这些石头被运送到另外一个区域被捣碎 以便提取金子
M2M100: 石头深度高达300英尺,它们将运送重型石袋,随后将运送到另一个区域,在那里石头将被粉碎,以便它们可以提取黄金。

en_test: At first glance, the pounding site seems full  of powerful men, but when we look closer,  we see some less fortunate working on the fringes,  and children too.
zh_test: 乍看之下，砸石场的男人个个健壮 但我们凑近了却发现 一些在边缘地带的工人身有残疾 还有一些小孩
M2M100: 从第一眼看,点击的场景看起来充满了强大的男人,但当我们看得更近时,我们看到一些不幸的人在边缘工作,孩子们也。

en_test: All of them are victim to injury, illness and violence.
zh_test: 他们都是伤病暴力的受害者
M2M100: 他们都是受伤、疾病和暴力的受害者。

en_test: In fact, it's very likely that this muscular person  will end up like this one here, racked with tuberculosis  and mercury poisoning in just a few years.
zh_test: 事实上，这些肌肉强健的男人 若干年后很有可能会跟这个人一样 被汞中毒和肺结核苦苦折磨
M2M100: 事实上,很可能这个肌肉的人会像这里那样结束,在几年内被结核病和水泥中毒所困扰。

en_test: This is Manuru. When his father died,  his uncle trafficked him to work with him in the mines.
zh_test: 这是Manuru。当他父亲死的时候 他的叔叔把他卖到自己在工作的这个矿场
M2M100: 當他的父親去世時,他的叔叔交易了他與他一起在礦場上工作。

en_test: When his uncle died, Manuru inherited his uncle's debt,  which further forced him into being enslaved in the mines.
zh_test: 在他叔叔死后，Manuru要继续背负他叔叔的欠债 他被迫继续在矿场工作
M2M100: 当他的叔叔去世时,曼努鲁继承了他的叔叔的债务,这使他进一步被迫在矿井里奴役。

en_test: When I met him, he had been working in the mines  for 14 years, and the leg injury that you see here  is actually from a mining accident,  one so severe doctors say his leg should be amputated.
zh_test: 我见到他时，他已在矿场工作了14年 照片中看到的这个腿伤 是在一次凿矿意外中造成的 当时情况危急，医生说要截肢
M2M100: 当我见到他时,他已经在矿井里工作了14年,你在这里看到的腿部受伤实际上是从矿业事故中产生的,一个如此严重的医生说他的腿应该被 amputat。

en_test: On top of that, Manuru has tuberculosis,  yet he's still forced to work day in and day out  in that mine shaft.
zh_test: 除了这个伤以外 他还患有肺结核 即使这样，他也必须每天 在井下没日没夜的工作
M2M100: 除此之外,曼鲁患有结核病,但他仍然被迫在那块矿井里工作一天一天。

en_test: Even still, he has a dream that he will become free  and become educated with the help of local activists  like Free the Slaves,  and it's this sort of determination,  in the face of unimaginable odds,  that fills me with complete awe.
zh_test: 即使如此，他也梦想着能够重获自由 在Free the Slaves这样的组织帮助下 接受教育 就是这样的信念 面对令人难以想象的苦难 让我充满敬畏
M2M100: 尽管如此,他仍然有一个梦想,他会自由,并在自由的奴隶等当地活动家的帮助下受教育,在无法想象的机会面前,这就是这种决心,让我充满了完全的恐惧。

en_test: I want to shine a light on slavery.
zh_test: 我希望我们给这些被奴隶的人一道光
M2M100: 我要照亮奴隶制。

en_test: When I was working in the field,  I brought lots of candles with me,  and with the help of my interpreter,  I imparted to the people I was photographing  that I wanted to illuminate their stories  and their plight,  so when it was safe for them, and safe for me,  I made these images.
zh_test: 当我在拍摄的途中 我带了很多蜡烛 在翻译的帮助下 我把蜡烛分给了我的拍摄对象 我希望能点亮他们的故事 和他们的困境 当我们都安全的时候 我拍了这一系列的照片
M2M100: 当我在现场工作时,我带了很多蜡烛,并在我的翻译员的帮助下,我向我正在拍摄的人们传达,我想照亮他们的故事和他们的麻烦,所以当它对他们来说是安全的,对我来说是安全的时,我做了这些图像。

en_test: They knew their image would be seen  by you out in the world.
zh_test: 他们知道这些影像 会被外面的人看见
M2M100: 他們知道他們的形象會被你在世界中看到。

en_test: I wanted them to know that we will be bearing witness  to them, and that we will do whatever we can  to help make a difference in their lives.
zh_test: 我想要让他们知道，我们将为他们作证 尽我们所能 让他们的人生有所改变
M2M100: 我希望他们知道,我们会为他们作见证,我们会尽我们所能帮助他们在他们的生活中做出差异。

en_test: I truly believe, if we can see one another  as fellow human beings, then it becomes very difficult  to tolerate atrocities like slavery.
zh_test: 我确实相信 当我们把他们当做同胞 就会很难容忍奴役这样的暴行
M2M100: 我真的相信,如果我们能互相看作是同人,那么忍受奴隶制等残酷行为就变得非常困难。

en_test: These images are not of issues. They are of people,  real people, like you and me, all deserving  of the same rights, dignity and respect  There is not a day that goes by that I don't think  of these many beautiful, mistreated people  I've had the tremendous honor of meeting.
zh_test: 这些影像非关于议题，而是关于人 真实的人，和你我一样 都值得在生命里 获得一样的权利、尊严和尊重 我没有一天不想 这些美丽、但却受到不公正待遇的人们 这些我三生有幸能够遇见的人们
M2M100: 这些图像不是问题,它们是人,真正的人,像你和我一样,所有人都值得同样的权利,尊严和尊重,没有一天我不会想到这些许多美丽的,迷误的人,我已经有相遇的巨大荣誉。

en_test: I hope that these images awaken a force  in those who view them, people like you,  and I hope that force will ignite a fire,  and that fire will shine a light on slavery,  for without that light, the beast of bondage  can continue to live in the shadows.
zh_test: 我希望这些影像 能够在你们这样的观者心中唤起一股力量 我希望这股力量的星星之火 能够成为被奴役者的希望之光 因为若没有这光亮 奴役之兽将继续活在阴影里
M2M100: 我希望这些图像在那些看到它们的人中产生力量,像你这样的人,我希望这种力量会燃烧火焰,火焰会照亮奴隶制,因为没有这种光,奴隶制的动物可以继续生活在阴影中。

en_test: Thank you very much.
zh_test: 谢谢大家
M2M100: 非常感谢你。

en_test: So, well, I do applied math,  for anyone who does applied math, is that  we are like management consultants.
zh_test: 话说，我是学应用数学的 对于每一个学应用数学的人来说 有一个特殊的难题，就是 我们和管理顾问都很像
M2M100: 所以,好吧,我做应用数学,对于任何做应用数学的人来说,我们就像管理顾问一样。

M2M100: 隨著時間的推移,更多的照片來了,幸運的是,需要更多的回報,所以我在Facebook和LinkedIn上再次發現,五天內,80人想從12個不同的國家幫助。

en_test: Within two weeks, I had 150 people  wanting to join in.

en_test: Within Japan, by July, we'd branched out  to the neighboring town of Rikuzentakata,  further north to a town called Yamada.

zh_test: 每周，我们都在 临时照相馆里架起扫描设备， 人们前来这些临时照相馆领回他们的照片。

en_test: The older ladies sometimes hadn't seen a scanner before,  but within 10 minutes of them finding their lost photo,  they could give it to us, have it scanned,  uploaded to a cloud server, it would be downloaded  by a gaijin, a stranger,  somewhere on the other side of the globe,  and it'd start being fixed.

en_test: After six months in Japan,  1,100 volunteers had passed through All Hands,  hundreds of whom had helped us hand-clean  over 135,000 photographs,  the large majority —  —  a large majority of which did actually find their home again,  importantly.

en_test: Over five hundred volunteers around the globe  helped us get 90 families hundreds of photographs back,  fully restored and retouched.

M2M100: 现在,技术学家、企业领袖和经济学家都基本上同意什么国家政策和国际条约会推动替代能源的发展:主要是能源研究和开发的显著增加,以及某种类型的碳价格。

en_test: But there's no hope in the present political climate  that we will see U.S. energy policy  or international treaties that reflect that consensus.

en_test: Sometimes, big problems that had seemed technological  turn out not to be so.
zh_test: 有些时候，那些看起来是科技上的大问题 其实却不是
M2M100: 有时,看起来技术上的重大问题并不如此。

en_test: Famines were long understood to be caused  by failures in food supply.
zh_test: 饥荒长期以来被认为是 食物短缺造成的
M2M100: 很久很久很久很久很久很久很久很久很久很久很久很久很久很久很久。

en_test: But 30 years of research have taught us  that famines are political crises  that catastrophically affect food distribution.
zh_test: 但通过30年的研究发现 饥荒是由于政治危机 灾难性地影响了食物分配造成的
M2M100: 但30年的研究已经教导我们饥饿是政治危机,这对食物分配产生了灾难性的影响。

en_test: Technology can improve things like crop yields  or systems for storing and transporting food,  but there will be famines so long as there are bad governments.
zh_test: 科技可以增加作物产量 或帮助食物的储存和运输 但是有糟糕的政府就会有饥荒
M2M100: 技术可以改善种植产量或食物存储和运输系统等事物,但只要有坏政府,就会有饥饿。

en_test: Finally, big problems sometimes elude solution  because we don't really understand the problem.
zh_test: 最后，一些大问题会被逃避解决 因为人们不了解这些问题
M2M100: 最后,大问题有时会错过解决方案,因为我们真的不明白问题。

en_test: President Nixon declared war on cancer in 1971,  but we soon discovered  there are many kinds of cancer,  most of them fiendishly resistant to therapy,  and it is only in the last 10 years  that effective, viable therapies  have come to seem real.
zh_test: 尼克松总统在1971年对癌症宣战 但我们很快发现 有太多种的癌症 大多数如恶魔般难以治疗 直到过去十年 有效可行的治疗方法 才开始出现
M2M100: 尼克森总统在1971年宣布对癌症的战争,但我们很快发现有许多类型的癌症,其中大多数是敌对抵抗治疗的,只有在过去的10年里,有效的可行治疗已经出现了现实。

en_test: Hard problems are hard.
zh_test: 困难的问题就是很难解决
M2M100: 艰难问题是艰难的。

en_test: It's not true that we can't solve big problems through technology.
zh_test: 这不代表科技无法解决大问题
M2M100: 事实上,我们不能通过技术解决重大问题。

en_test: We can, we must, but these four elements  must all be present:  Political leaders and the public  must care to solve a problem;  institutions must support its solution;  It must really be a technological problem;  and we must understand it.
zh_test: 我们可以，但以下四个要素 要同时满足 政治领袖和群众 必须关心解决这个问题 必须有机构支持其解决方案 其必须是技术上的问题 我们必须了解它
M2M100: 我们可以,我们必须,但这些四个元素都必须存在:政治领袖和公众必须关心解决问题;机构必须支持解决问题;它必须真正成为技术问题;我们必须理解它。

en_test: The Apollo mission,  which has become a kind of metaphor  for technology's capacity to solve big problems,  met these criteria.
zh_test: 阿波罗计划 已经成为科技能够 解决大问题的象征 便符合这些要素
M2M100: 阿波罗任务已成为技术解决重大问题能力的一种形象,满足了这些标准。

en_test: But it is an irreproducible model for the future.
zh_test: 但这是一个不可复制的案例
M2M100: 但它是未来的不可再生模型。

en_test: It is not 1961.
zh_test: 现在已经不是1961年

en_test: There is no galvanizing contest like the Cold War,  no politician like John Kennedy  who can heroize the difficult and the dangerous,  and no popular science fictional mythology  such as exploring the solar system.
zh_test: 已经没有冷战中的军备竞赛 已经没有肯尼迪这样的政治家 会给困难和危险披上英雄主义色彩 没有流行的科幻神话 例如探索太阳系
M2M100: 没有像冷战那样激动人心的竞赛,没有像约翰·肯尼迪那样的政治家能够英雄化困难和危险,也没有像探索太阳系那样流行的科幻神话。

en_test: Most of all, going to the moon  turned out to be easy.
zh_test: 最重要的是，去月球 已经变得容易

en_test: It was just three days away.

en_test: And arguably it wasn't even solving  much of a problem.

M2M100: 显然,它甚至没有解决很多问题。

en_test: We are left alone with our day,  and the solutions of the future will be harder won.
zh_test: 我们继续着我们的生活 而未来的问题将更难解决
M2M100: 我們與我們的日子孤單,未來的解決方案將更難獲得。

en_test: God knows, we don't lack for the challenges.

en_test: Thank you very much.

en_test: So I'm going to talk about trust,  and I'm going to start by reminding you  of the standard views that people have about trust.

M2M100: 所以我要谈论信任,我要先提醒你人们对信任的标准观点。

en_test: I think these are so commonplace,  they've become clichés of our society.
zh_test: 我觉得这些观点都很司空见惯， 在现实社会已经变成陈词滥调了。
M2M100: 我认为这些是如此常见的地方,它们已经成为我们社会的幻想。

en_test: And I think there are three.
zh_test: 我想一共有这样三点。
M2M100: 我认为有三个。

en_test: One's a claim: there has been a great decline in trust,  very widely believed.
zh_test: 第一点是主张：信任感已经大幅地降低了。 这已经是有广泛共识的。
M2M100: 有一個說法:信任已經大幅下降,非常普遍地相信。

en_test: The second is an aim: we should have more trust.
zh_test: 第二点是目的：我们应该有更多的信任感。
M2M100: 第二个目标是:我们应该有更多的信心。

en_test: And the third is a task: we should rebuild trust.
zh_test: 第三点是任务：我们应该重建信任感。
M2M100: 第三个任务是:我们应该重新建立信任。

en_test: I think that the claim, the aim and the task  are all misconceived.
zh_test: 我觉得人们对这个主张、目的和任务 都有错误的认识。
M2M100: 我认为这项要求、目标和任务都是错误的。

en_test: So what I'm going to try to tell you today  is a different story about a claim, an aim and a task  which I think give one quite a lot better purchase on the matter.

M2M100: 因此,我今天要试着告诉你一个不同的故事,关于一个要求,一个目标和一个任务,我认为给一个更好的购买这个问题。

zh_test: 首先是主张：为什么人们认为信任感在降低呢？

en_test: And if I really think about it on the basis of my own evidence,  I don't know the answer.

M2M100: 如果我真的基于自己的证据,我不知道答案。

en_test: I'm inclined to think it may have declined  in some activities or some institutions  and it might have grown in others.
zh_test: 我倾向于认为信任感确实是有降低， 但那是在某些活动中，或者在某些机构里。 而在其他的方面也许是增加的。
M2M100: 我倾向于认为它可能在某些活动或某些机构中下降,并且可能在其他机构中增长。

en_test: I don't have an overview.
zh_test: 我没法一概而论。
M2M100: 我没有概述。

en_test: But, of course, I can look at the opinion polls,  and the opinion polls are supposedly  the source of a belief that trust has declined.

M2M100: 但是,当然,我可以看看观点调查,观点调查据称是信任下降的信念来源。

en_test: When you actually look at opinion polls across time,  there's not much evidence for that.
zh_test: 但当你真的去看看不同时间的民意调查的话， 其实没有多少证据支持这个观点。
M2M100: 當你實際上隨著時間的推移看意見調查時,沒有太多證據。

en_test: That's to say, the people who were mistrusted  20 years ago,  principally journalists and politicians, are still mistrusted.
zh_test: 也就是说，那些 在20年前就不被相信的人 主要是记者和政客，现在仍不被信任。
M2M100: 也就是说,20年前失望的人,主要是记者和政治家,仍然失望。

en_test: And the people who were highly trusted 20 years ago  are still rather highly trusted: judges, nurses.
zh_test: 而20年前就被高度信任的人， 比如法官和护士，现在仍得到高度的信任。
M2M100: 20年前非常有信心的人仍然非常有信心:法官,护士。

en_test: The rest of us are in between,  and by the way, the average person in the street  is almost exactly midway.

M2M100: 其余的我们在中间,而在路上,街道上的平均人几乎是正确的中间。

en_test: But is that good evidence?
zh_test: 但是这个证据说得过去吗？
M2M100: 这是好证据吗?

en_test: What opinion polls record is, of course, opinions.
zh_test: 民意调查记录的当然就是一些人们的观点。

M2M100: 他们还能记录什么?

en_test: So they're looking at the generic attitudes  that people report when you ask them certain questions.
zh_test: 不过就是一些普遍的态度。 你问他们什么，他们就说什么。
M2M100: 因此,他们正在观察人们在问他们某些问题时报告的普遍态度。

en_test: Do you trust politicians? Do you trust teachers?
zh_test: 你信任政客吗？信任老师吗？

M2M100: 你信任渔民吗?

en_test: Do you trust elementary school teachers?"
zh_test: 你信任小学老师吗？
M2M100: “你信任小学教师吗?”

en_test: you would probably begin by saying, "To do what?"
zh_test: 你可能会问，“信任他们去做什么？”

en_test: And that would be a perfectly sensible response.
zh_test: 这是一个非常明智的反问。

en_test: And you might say, when you understood the answer to that,  "Well, I trust some of them, but not others."
zh_test: 当你明白问题到底是什么, 你会说， “嗯。我相信一些人，不相信另一些人。”
M2M100: 當你明白答案時,你可能會說:「好吧,我信任一些人,而不是其他人。

en_test: That's a perfectly rational thing.
zh_test: 非常理性的回答。
M2M100: 这是一个完全合理的事情。

en_test: In short, in our real lives,  we seek to place trust in a differentiated way.
zh_test: 简而言之，在我们现实生活中， 我们以不同的方式来寻求信任。
M2M100: 简而言之,在我们的现实生活中,我们试图以不同的方式建立信任。

en_test: We don't make an assumption that the level of trust  that we will have in every instance of a certain type  of official or office-holder or type of person  is going to be uniform.
zh_test: 我们不对信任感的程度做假设。 我们会对特定类型进行具体分析。 那些公务员，官员之类的人， 会被类型化。
M2M100: 我们不会假设我们在某种形式的官员或官员或人类的每个案例中所拥有的信任水平将是均匀的。

en_test: I might, for example, say that I certainly trust  a certain elementary school teacher I know  to teach the reception class to read,  but in no way to drive the school minibus.
zh_test: 比如说，我会说我当然相信 一个我知道的小学老师 会教会学生怎么阅读。 但是我不相信她可以开校车。
M2M100: 例如,我可以说,我肯定会信任某个小学教师,我知道如何教导接待课堂阅读,但没有办法驾驶学校小公交车。

en_test: I might, after all, know that she wasn't a good driver.
zh_test: 也许最终我知道她确实不是个好司机。
M2M100: 毕竟,我可能知道她不是一个好司机。

en_test: I might trust my most loquacious friend  to keep a conversation going  but not -- but perhaps not to keep a secret.
zh_test: 我也许相信我那爱喝酒的朋友 是个聊天的好伙伴。 但我不会相信他是个守得住秘密的人。
M2M100: 我可以信任我最可爱的朋友保持谈话,但不是 - 但也许不是保持一个秘密。

en_test: Simple.
zh_test: 就这么简单。
M2M100: 简单。

en_test: So if we've got those evidence in our ordinary lives  of the way that trust is differentiated,  why do we sort of drop all that intelligence  when we think about trust more abstractly?
zh_test: 在日常生活中我们有了这样的证据， 说信任感是有区分的， 那么为什么民意调查时我们一下子糊涂了， 把信任感想得更概念化了呢？
M2M100: 因此,如果我们在我们平凡的生活中有这些证据表明信任是如何区分的,那么当我们更抽象地思考信任时,我们为什么会放弃这一切的智慧呢?

en_test: I think the polls are very bad guides  to the level of trust that actually exists,  because they try to obliterate the good judgment  that goes into placing trust.
zh_test: 我觉得民意调查是个很差劲的 衡量信任感是否存在的依据。 因为它抹杀了人们良好的判断力。 对考虑信任感的判断力。
M2M100: 我认为这些调查是对实际存在的信任水平的非常糟糕的指南,因为它们试图揭露信任的良好判断。

en_test: Secondly, what about the aim?
zh_test: 第二，那个目的是怎么回事儿呢？
M2M100: 其次,目标怎么样?

en_test: The aim is to have more trust.
zh_test: 目的是我们需要更多的信任感。
M2M100: 我们的目标是获得更多的信任。

en_test: Well frankly, I think that's a stupid aim.
zh_test: 坦白说，我觉得这个目的挺可笑的。

en_test: It's not what I would aim at.
zh_test: 这不是我想的那个目的。

en_test: I would aim to have more trust in the trustworthy  but not in the untrustworthy.
zh_test: 我会说，人们应该对值得信赖的更加地信任。 而不是去信任不值得信赖的人。
M2M100: 我希望有更多的信任可靠的人,而不是不信任的人。

en_test: In fact, I aim positively to try not to trust the untrustworthy.
zh_test: 实际上，我所说的目的是尽量不要信任不值得信赖的人。
M2M100: 事实上,我的目标是积极地试图不信任不信任的人。

en_test: And I think, of those people who, for example,  placed their savings with the very aptly named Mr. Madoff,  who then made off with them,  and I think of them, and I think, well, yes,  too much trust.
zh_test: 比如说，那些 把自己的积蓄交给那个看起来很象样的 却把他们的钱都卷走的麦道夫先生 的人，我觉得那些人呀，怎么说呢，对， 太容易信任别人了。
M2M100: 我想,那些人,例如,把他们的储蓄放在一个非常合适的名叫Madoff先生,谁然后与他们交往,我想他们,我想,好,是的,太信任。

en_test: More trust is not an intelligent aim in this life.
zh_test: 过度地信任别人不是一个很明智的目的。

en_test: Intelligently placed and intelligently refused trust  is the proper aim.
zh_test: 明智地信任和明智地选择不信任 才是正确的目的。
M2M100: 智慧地放置和智慧地拒绝的信任是正确的目标。

en_test: Well once one says that, one says, yeah, okay,  that means that what matters in the first place  is not trust but trustworthiness.

M2M100: 好吧,一旦有人说,有人说,是的,好吧,这意味着首先重要的是不是信任,而是信任。

en_test: It's judging how trustworthy people are  in particular respects.
zh_test: 就是说要判断别人在某些方面 是否值得信任。

en_test: And I think that judgment requires us to look at three things.
zh_test: 我觉得要想正确做出判断需要考虑三点。
M2M100: 我认为判断需要我们看看三件事。

en_test: Are they competent? Are they honest? Are they reliable?
zh_test: 要看他们是否称职？是否诚实？是否可靠？

en_test: And if we find that a person is competent  in the relevant matters,  and reliable and honest,  we'll have a pretty good reason to trust them,  because they'll be trustworthy.
zh_test: 如果我们觉得一个人是称职的， 在他自己的领域是称职的。 而且是诚实可靠的。 我们就有理由去相信他们， 因为他们是可信赖的。

en_test: If so, I haven't yet spotted it.

en_test: But that's what we're looking for:  trustworthiness before trust.

en_test: And all over our public life, our institutional life,  we find that problem,  that the system of accountability  that is meant to secure trustworthiness  and evidence of trustworthiness  is actually doing the opposite.
zh_test: 在我们的公共生活里，我们的机构生活里， 我们发现很多问题。 这些机构里的问责制度 这些能保障自己的信誉 能作为值得信任的依据的制度 往往施行起来是相反的。

en_test: It is distracting people who have to do difficult tasks,  like midwives, from doing them  by requiring them to tick the boxes, as we say.

en_test: And this gap has become shorter,  shorter, and even shorter,  and now this gap is shortened down  to less than a millimeter,  the thickness of a touch-screen glass,  and the power of computing  has become accessible to everyone.

en_test: At Microsoft Applied Sciences,  along with my mentor Cati Boulanger,  I redesigned the computer  and turned a little space above the keyboard  into a digital workspace.
zh_test: 我在微软应用科学实验室， 和我的导师卡迪•布兰葛 重新设计了这台计算机 把键盘上方的小空间 挪进数字工作区内。

en_test: At MIT Media Lab, along with my advisor Hiroshi Ishii  and my collaborator Rehmi Post,  we created this one physical pixel.

en_test: Well, in this case, this spherical magnet  acts like a 3D pixel in our space,  which means that both computers and people  can move this object to anywhere  within this little 3D space.
zh_test: 在这种情况下，这个球形磁体 就好像是我们空间中的一个三维像素点， 这就意味着计算机和人 可以将这个物体移动到 这一三维立体小空间的任何位置。

en_test: What we did was essentially canceling gravity  and controlling the movement by combining  magnetic levitation and mechanical actuation  and sensing technologies.
zh_test: 我们的基本实现原理是，消除重力对小球的作用 并通过磁悬浮、机械驱动 和传感技术的结合 来控制小球的运动。
M2M100: 我们所做的是基本上取消重力,并通过结合磁性振动和机械行动和传感技术来控制运动。

en_test: And by digitally programming the object,  we are liberating the object from constraints  of time and space, which means that now,  human motions can be recorded and played back  and left permanently in the physical world.
zh_test: 通过对这个对象的数字编程， 我们正试着解放 时间和空间对物质的限制，这意味着，现在， 人的运动可以在物质世界中可以被 录制、重放和永久保留。

M2M100: 学生可以使用它作为一个工具,了解复杂的概念,如行星运动,物理学,与计算机屏幕或文本不同,这是一个真实的,有意义的体验,你可以触摸和感觉,它是非常强大的。

en_test: And what's more exciting  than just turning what's currently in the computer physical  is to start imagining how programming the world  will alter even our daily physical activities.
zh_test: 更令人兴奋的是， 这不止是把当前计算机的东西转变为真实的物质， 而是开始想象，编程的世界甚至将 改变我们日常的体能活动。
M2M100: 而更令人兴奋的是,只是在计算机物理学中转变现在的东西就是开始想象如何编程世界甚至会改变我们的日常物理活动。

en_test: We went to the National Spelling Bee  and tried to predict which children would advance farthest in competition.

M2M100: 我们去到了国家喷发蜜蜂,试图预测哪个孩子在比赛中最快的进展。

en_test: We studied rookie teachers working in really tough neighborhoods,  asking which teachers are still going to be here in teaching  by the end of the school year,  and of those, who will be the most effective  at improving learning outcomes for their students?
zh_test: 我们研究在恶劣的工作环境下工作的， 刚入行的老师，询问他们 哪些老师决定会在学年结束后 继续留下来任教， 以及他们之中谁能最快地 提高学生的学习成绩。
M2M100: 我们研究了在真正艰难的地区工作的罗基教师,问哪些教师在学年结束时仍然会在这里教学,以及那些谁会最有效地改善他们的学生的学习成果?

en_test: We partnered with private companies, asking,  which of these salespeople is going to keep their jobs?
zh_test: 我们与私企合作，向他们询问 哪些销售人员可以保住工作，
M2M100: 我们与私人公司合作,问,这些销售人员中哪个将保持工作?

en_test: And who's going to earn the most money?
zh_test: 哪些可以赚钱最多？
M2M100: 谁会赚最多的钱?

en_test: In all those very different contexts,  one characteristic emerged as a significant predictor of success.
zh_test: 在所有那些不同的情境下， 一种性格特征凸显了出来， 这种特征在很大程度上预示了成功。
M2M100: 在所有这些非常不同的背景下,一个特征出现为成功的显著预测器。

en_test: And it wasn't social intelligence.
zh_test: 而且它并不是社交智力。
M2M100: 这不是社交智能。

en_test: It wasn't good looks, physical health, and it wasn't IQ.
zh_test: 不是漂亮的外表，强健的体魄，也不是很高的IQ，
M2M100: 它看起来不太好,身体健康,并且它不是IQ。

en_test: It was grit.
zh_test: 它是毅力。
M2M100: 那是尖叫。

en_test: Grit is passion and perseverance for very long-term goals.
zh_test: 毅力是对长远目标的激情和坚持，
M2M100: 哭是对长期目标的热情和耐心。

en_test: Grit is having stamina.
zh_test: 毅力是拥有持久的恒劲，
M2M100: 格里特有耐力。

en_test: Grit is sticking with your future, day in, day out,  not just for the week, not just for the month,  but for years,  and working really hard to make that future a reality.
zh_test: 毅力是你对未来的坚持，日复一日 不是仅仅持续一个星期或者一个月， 而是几年甚至几十年努力奋斗着 让自己的梦想变为现实。
M2M100: 格里特与你的未来,白天,白天,不只是一个星期,不只是一个月,但多年,工作真的很努力,使这个未来成为现实。

en_test: Grit is living life like it's a marathon, not a sprint.
zh_test: 毅力是把生活当成一场马拉松而不是一次短跑。
M2M100: 哭是生活,就像是马拉松,而不是斯普林特。

en_test: A few years ago,  I started studying grit in the Chicago public schools.
zh_test: 几年前，在芝加哥的公立学校里， 我开始研究毅力。
M2M100: 几年前,我开始在芝加哥公立学校学习格里特。

en_test: I asked thousands of high school juniors  to take grit questionnaires,  and then waited around more than a year  to see who would graduate.
zh_test: 我对上千名初中生进行了 关于毅力的问卷调查， 然后等候了一年多， 来看最终哪些学生能毕业。
M2M100: 我要求成千上万的高中青少年接收大声问卷,然后等了一年多,看看谁会毕业。

en_test: Turns out that grittier kids  were significantly more likely to graduate,  even when I matched them on every characteristic I could measure,  things like family income,  standardized achievement test scores,  even how safe kids felt when they were at school.
zh_test: 结果证明那些更具毅力的学生 在毕业的概率上占绝对优势， 即使是在同样可以量化的外在因素下 像家庭收入， 标准化成绩测验的分数， 甚至是孩子们在学校能获得多少安全感之类，仍是有毅力的学生更容易毕业
M2M100: 显然,愤怒的孩子们更有可能毕业,即使我把它们匹配到我能测量的每一个特征上,例如家庭收入、标准化成就测试成绩,甚至孩子们在上学时感到多么安全。

en_test: So it's not just at West Point or the National Spelling Bee  that grit matters. It's also in school,  especially for kids at risk for dropping out.
zh_test: 所有不仅仅是在西点军校里或者全国拼字比赛上 才需要毅力。在学校亦是如此， 尤其是对于那些徘徊在辍学边缘的孩子们。
M2M100: 因此,这不仅仅是西点或国家<unk>蜂会大喊大叫,而且在学校,尤其是孩子们面临脱落的风险。

en_test: To me, the most shocking thing about grit  is how little we know,  how little science knows, about building it.
zh_test: 对于我自己来说，关于毅力最让我震惊的事情莫过于 对于毅力，我们知之甚少， 在培养毅力上，科学对理解的认识又是何等贫乏。
M2M100: 对于我来说,关于尖叫的最令人震惊的是我们知道多少,科学知道多少,建造它。

en_test: Every day, parents and teachers ask me,  "How do I build grit in kids?
zh_test: 每天都有家长和老师来问我， “我怎样做才能培养孩子的毅力呢?
M2M100: 每一天,父母和老师都问我:“我如何在孩子们中建造尖叫?

en_test: What do I do to teach kids a solid work ethic?
zh_test: 该做些什么才能教授给孩子们真正的职业道德？
M2M100: 我该怎么做才能教孩子一个坚实的工作道德?

en_test: How do I keep them motivated for the long run?"
zh_test: 又该怎样调动他们长期的积极性呢？”
M2M100: “我怎么能让他们长时间动机呢?”

en_test: The honest answer is, I don't know.   What I do know is that talent doesn't make you gritty.
zh_test: 老实说，我不知道。 我所知道的是，才华并不能使你坚韧不拔。
M2M100: 正直的答案是,我不知道,我知道的是,才华不会让你大喊大叫。

en_test: Our data show very clearly  that there are many talented individuals  who simply do not follow through on their commitments.
zh_test: 我们的数据十分清楚地表明， 有许多才华横溢的人， 他们都无法坚持兑现自己的承诺。
M2M100: 我们的数据很清楚地表明,有很多有才华的人,他们只是不遵循他们的承诺。

en_test: In fact, in our data, grit is usually unrelated  or even inversely related to measures of talent.
zh_test: 事实上，根据我们的数据来看，毅力通常与其他因素无关， 甚至与才华的衡量标准背道而驰。
M2M100: 事实上,在我们的数据中,格里特通常与天赋的测量无关,甚至相反。

en_test: So far, the best idea I've heard about building grit in kids  is something called "growth mindset."
zh_test: 到目前为止，我所听说过的在孩子身上培养坚韧品质最有效的方法 叫“成长型思维模式。”
M2M100: 到目前为止,我听说过关于在儿童中构建的最好的想法是所谓的“成长思维”。

en_test: This is an idea developed at Stanford University by Carol Dweck,  and it is the belief that the ability to learn is not fixed,  that it can change with your effort.
zh_test: 斯坦福大学卡洛杜威克提出过一个观点， 他相信 人的学习能力是可变的， 它随着你的努力程度而变化。
M2M100: 这是一项由卡罗尔·杜克在斯坦福大学开发的想法,并相信学习能力不是固定的,它可以随着你的努力而改变。

en_test: Dr. Dweck has shown that when kids read and learn about the brain  and how it changes and grows in response to challenge,  they're much more likely to persevere when they fail,  because they don't believe that failure is a permanent condition.
zh_test: 杜威克教授表示，当孩子们阅读和学习有关大脑的知识 以及它在面对挑战时 所发生的变化和成长情况， 他们失败之后更容易坚持下去， 因为他们 不相信会一直失败下去。
M2M100: 杜克博士已经表明,当孩子们阅读和学习大脑以及它如何改变和成长作为回应挑战时,他们更有可能在失败时坚持下去,因为他们不相信失败是一种永久性状态。

en_test: So growth mindset is a great idea for building grit.
zh_test: 因此，成长性思维模式对培养毅力大有裨益。
M2M100: 因此,成长思维是一个伟大的想法,建造网格。

en_test: But we need more.
zh_test: 但是我们需要更多。
M2M100: 但我们需要更多。

en_test: And that's where I'm going to end my remarks,  because that's where we are.
zh_test: 我决定在此结束我的评论， 因为我们正在经历着这一切。
M2M100: 这就是我要结束我的评论,因为这就是我们所在的地方。

en_test: That's the work that stands before us.
zh_test: 这是眼前所面临的工作。
M2M100: 这就是在我们面前站着的工作。

en_test: We need to take our best ideas, our strongest intuitions,  and we need to test them.
zh_test: 我们要拿出最好的想法和最强的直觉， 我们要对他们进行实践。
M2M100: 我们需要采取最好的想法,我们最强的直觉,我们需要测试它们。

en_test: We need to measure whether we've been successful,  and we have to be willing to fail, to be wrong,  to start over again with lessons learned.
zh_test: 我们需要估量这一切是否成功 同时还要渴望对失败和错误， 要从这些失败中汲取经验重新再来。
M2M100: 我们需要衡量我们是否成功,我们必须愿意失败,错误,重新开始学习的教训。

en_test: In other words, we need to be gritty  about getting our kids grittier.
zh_test: 换句话说，我们只有自己变得更有毅力 才能让我们的孩子变得更有毅力。
M2M100: 换句话说,我们必须为让我们的孩子大喊大叫。

en_test: Thank you.
zh_test: 谢谢大家！
M2M100: 谢谢你

en_test: Growing up in Taiwan  as the daughter of a calligrapher,  one of my most treasured memories  was my mother showing me the beauty, the shape  and the form of Chinese characters.
zh_test: 我在台湾长大。 作为一位书法家的女儿， 我最珍贵的记忆之一 是妈妈为我展示了 汉字的形意之美。
M2M100: 在台湾长大,作为一个卡利格拉弗的女儿,我最珍惜的记忆之一是我母亲向我展示了中国人物的美丽、形状和形状。

en_test: Ever since then, I was fascinated  by this incredible language.
zh_test: 从那时起， 我开始着迷于这美妙的语言。
M2M100: 从那时起,我对这个令人难以置信的语言感到兴奋。

en_test: But to an outsider, it seems to be  as impenetrable as the Great Wall of China.
zh_test: 但对于门外汉来说， 汉字就跟中国的长城一样 高不可攀。
M2M100: 但对于一个外观人士来说,它似乎像中国大墙那样不可侵犯。

en_test: Over the past few years, I've been wondering  if I can break down this wall,  so anyone who wants to understand and appreciate  the beauty of this sophisticated language could do so.
zh_test: 过去几年，我一直思考 如何能够攻克这堵墙， 让那些要理解和欣赏 这复杂语言优雅地方的人， 可以这样做。
M2M100: 在过去的几年里,我一直在想我是否能打破这堵墙,所以任何想理解和欣赏这个精致的语言的美丽的人都可以这样做。

en_test: I started thinking about how a new, fast method  of learning Chinese might be useful.
zh_test: 我开始思考，如何创造一种新的、 快速的方法， 有助于学习汉字。
M2M100: 我开始思考如何一个新的,快速的方法学习中国可以有用。

en_test: Since the age of five, I started to learn how to draw  every single stroke for each character  in the correct sequence.
zh_test: 从五岁起，我开始学习 如何按照正确顺序、一笔一划的 书写每个汉字。
M2M100: 从五岁开始,我开始学习如何在正确的序列中为每个角色绘制每个单击。

en_test: I learned new characters every day  Since we only have five minutes,  it's better that we have a fast and simpler way.
zh_test: 我每天都学习新的汉字。 因为我们只有五分钟时间， 最好有一个更简易便捷的学习方式。
M2M100: 我每天学习新的角色 因为我们只有五分钟,我们最好有一个更快、更简单的方式。

en_test: A Chinese scholar would understand 20,000 characters.
zh_test: 一位中文学者认识二万个汉字，
M2M100: 一个中国学者可以理解20000个字符。

en_test: You only need 1,000 to understand the basic literacy.
zh_test: 你只需认识一千个汉字， 就可看懂简单的文学作品。
M2M100: 你只需要一千来理解基本文学。

en_test: The top 200 will allow you to comprehend  40 percent of basic literature --  enough to read road signs, restaurant menus,  to understand the basic idea of the web pages  or the newspapers.
zh_test: 认识顶部二百个汉字， 让你看明白百分之四十的基本文献—— 足以读懂路标、餐厅菜单、 以了解中文网页的基本想法 或报纸内容。
M2M100: 顶级200将允许您了解40%的基本文学 - 足以阅读路线标志,餐厅菜单,了解网页或报纸的基本想法。

en_test: Today I'm going to start with eight  to show you how the method works.
zh_test: 今天我用八个汉字 来展示这个方法如何有效。

en_test: If the shape of the fire is a person  with two arms on both sides,  as if she was yelling frantically,  "Help! I'm on fire!" --  This symbol actually is originally from the shape of the flame,  but I like to think that way. Whichever works for you.

en_test: And this work has been wonderful. It's been great.

M2M100: 这个工作是很棒的,很棒的。

en_test: But it also has some fundamental  limitations so far.

M2M100: 但到目前为止,它还有一些基本限制。

en_test: The centerpiece  of the science of consciousness in recent years  has been the search for correlations,  correlations between certain areas of the brain  and certain states of consciousness.
zh_test: 近几年 意识科学研究的核心 是寻找相关性， 关于大脑的特定区域 和特定的意识状态之间的相关性。

en_test: We saw some of this kind of work  from Nancy Kanwisher and the wonderful work  she presented just a few minutes ago.
zh_test: 我们看了南希·坎维舍 做的一些这方面的研究以及几分钟之前 她刚刚提交的精彩工作。

zh_test: 现在我们有了更好的理解，例如， 不同的大脑区域对应着不同 的意识体验：人脸识别 或者感受痛苦 或者感受快乐。

en_test: We know that these brain areas  go along with certain kinds of conscious experience,  but we don't know why they do.

en_test: But in a certain sense, those are the easy problems.

en_test: It'll turn out to be another emergent phenomenon  like traffic jams, like hurricanes,  like life, and we'll figure it out.

en_test: The classical cases of emergence  are all cases of emergent behavior,  how a traffic jam behaves,  how a hurricane functions,  how a living organism reproduces  and adapts and metabolizes,  all questions about objective functioning.
zh_test: 所有涌现现象的经典案例 都是应急行为的表现， 塞车是如何行成的， 飓风是如何作用的， 生物体是如何繁殖、 适应环境和新陈代谢的， 所有这些问题都是关于客观机能的。

en_test: You could apply that to the human brain  in explaining some of the behaviors  and the functions of the human brain  as emergent phenomena:  how we walk, how we talk, how we play chess,  all these questions about behavior.
zh_test: 你可以把它应用到人类的大脑上 去解释为什么人类大脑的某些行为 和功能 跟涌现现象很像： 我们如何走路，如何谈话，如何下象棋， 所有这些问题都是关于行为的。
M2M100: 你可以将这一点应用到人类大脑中,解释人类大脑的一些行为和功能作为新兴现象:我们如何走路,我们如何说话,我们如何玩象棋,所有这些关于行为的问题。

en_test: But when it comes to consciousness,  questions about behavior  are among the easy problems.
zh_test: 但是当谈到意识时， 关于行为的问题 只是一个简单的问题。

en_test: When it comes to the hard problem,  that's the question of why is it  that all this behavior  is accompanied by subjective experience?

en_test: Now, I'm a scientific materialist at heart.
zh_test: 现在，我本质上是一个科学唯物主义者。

en_test: I want a scientific theory of consciousness  that works,  and for a long time, I banged my head  against the wall  looking for a theory of consciousness  in purely physical terms  that would work.
zh_test: 我希望某种关于意识的科学理论 能够奏效， 在过去很长一段时间里， 我埋头苦干， 努力寻找一种有效的 单从物理的角度去解释的 关于意识的理论。

en_test: But I eventually came to the conclusion  that that just didn't work for systematic reasons.
zh_test: 但我最终得出一个结论， 那就是它不起作用只是因为系统性的原因。
M2M100: 但我最终得出结论,这只是因为系统原因而不起作用。

en_test: It's a long story,  but the core idea is just that what you get  from purely reductionist explanations in physical terms, in brain-based terms,  is stories about the functioning of a system,  its structure, its dynamics,  the behavior it produces,  great for solving the easy problems —  how we behave, how we function —  but when it comes to subjective experience —  why does all this feel like something from the inside? —
zh_test: 说来话长， 但是这个故事的核心就是 你从在物理方面，在基于大脑方面的 纯粹的还原论者的解释中得到的东西， 是关于一个系统的功能、 它的结构、它的动力、 以及它所产生的行为的， 它可以很好地解决简单问题—— 比如说我们如何表现，我们如何活动—— 但是当它涉及到主观体验时—— 比如说为什么所有这些都感觉像是来自内心的某些东西？——

en_test: that's something fundamentally new,  and it's always a further question.

en_test: So I think we're at a kind of impasse here.

en_test: We've got this wonderful, great chain of explanation,  we're used to it, where physics explains chemistry,  chemistry explains biology,  biology explains parts of psychology.
zh_test: 我们已经有了一套美妙的、伟大的解释链， 我们已经习惯了它，那就是用用物理解释化学， 用化学解释生物， 用生物解释部分心理学。

en_test: On the one hand, it's a datum  that we're conscious.

en_test: On the other hand, we don't know how  to accommodate it into our scientific view of the world.

en_test: So I think consciousness right now  is a kind of anomaly,  one that we need to integrate  into our view of the world, but we don't yet see how.

en_test: This view is sometimes called panpsychism:  pan for all, psych for mind,  every system is conscious,  not just humans, dogs, mice, flies,  but even Rob Knight's microbes,  elementary particles.
zh_test: 这种观点有时被称作泛心论： 万物皆有精神或心理活动， 每个系统都具有意识， 不仅是人类、狗、老鼠、苍蝇， 甚至连罗伯·奈特的微生物、 基本粒子都具有意识。

en_test: Even a photon has some degree of consciousness.

M2M100: 这不是一个光子被恐惧所困扰,因为它想着,“哦,我总是靠近光的速度。

en_test: If it's fundamental, like space and time and mass,  it's natural to suppose that it might be universal too,  the way they are.

en_test: It's also worth noting that although the idea  seems counterintuitive to us,  it's much less counterintuitive to people  from different cultures,  where the human mind is seen as much more  continuous with nature.
zh_test: 还有一点值得注意的是虽然这个想法 对我们来说是违反直觉的， 但对来自其他文化的人来说 可能就不是那么违反直觉了， 那些人的心灵 跟自然联系在一起的时间更长。

en_test: A deeper motivation comes from the idea that  perhaps the most simple and powerful way  to find fundamental laws connecting consciousness  to physical processing  is to link consciousness to information.

en_test: A really exciting thing is in recent years  a neuroscientist, Giulio Tononi,  has taken this kind of theory  and developed it rigorously  with a mathematical theory.

en_test: He has a mathematical measure  of information integration  which he calls phi,  measuring the amount of information  integrated in a system.

en_test: So in a human brain,  incredibly large amount of information integration,  high degree of phi,  a whole lot of consciousness.

en_test: But as you go down to worms,  microbes, particles,  the amount of phi falls off.

en_test: On Tononi's theory,  there's still going to be a non-zero degree  of consciousness.

en_test: In effect, he's proposing a fundamental law  of consciousness: high phi, high consciousness.

en_test: Now, I don't know if this theory is right,  but it's actually perhaps the leading theory right now  in the science of consciousness,  and it's been used to integrate a whole range  of scientific data,  and it does have a nice property that it is in fact simple enough  you can write it on the front of a t-shirt.

en_test: Another final motivation is that  panpsychism might help us to integrate  consciousness into the physical world.

M2M100: 我没有做任何可以被认为是一个成就,如果你从平衡中取出残疾。

en_test: Years later, I was on my second teaching round  in a Melbourne high school,  and I was about 20 minutes into a year 11 legal studies class  when this boy put up his hand and said,  "Hey miss, when are you going to start doing your speech?"
zh_test: 几年以后，我再次回到 一个墨尔本高中的教书， 当我在11年级的一堂法律课上刚讲了大概20分钟时， 一个男孩举手问道： “女士，你什么时候才能开始演讲？”
M2M100: 几年后,我在墨尔本一所高中第二学期,当这个男孩举起手,说:“小姐,你什么时候会开始做你的演讲?”

en_test: And I said, "What speech?"
zh_test: 我说：”什么演讲？“
M2M100: 我又说:“什么演讲?”

en_test: You know, I'd been talking them  about defamation law for a good 20 minutes.
zh_test: 事实上，我已经就诽谤法 讲了二十多分钟了。
M2M100: 你知道,我会在20分钟内对他们谈论欺骗法。

en_test: And he said, "You know, like,  your motivational speaking.
zh_test: 然后他说：”比方说 励志演说什么的。
M2M100: 他说:“你知道你的动机说话。

en_test: You know, when people in wheelchairs come to school,  they usually say, like, inspirational stuff?"
zh_test: 当坐着轮椅的人来到学校， 他们一般都会说一些鼓舞人心的故事，是吧？“
M2M100: 你知道,当轮椅的人来到学校时,他们通常会说,好,有启发性的东西吗?”

en_test: "It's usually in the big hall."
zh_test: ”不过这种演讲一般都是在大报告厅里进行的呀。“
M2M100: “通常在大厅里。

en_test: And that's when it dawned on me:  This kid had only ever experienced disabled people  as objects of inspiration.
zh_test: 就是在那个时候我开始意识到： 这孩子一直把残障人士当做 一种励志对象。
M2M100: 这就是当我醒来时:这个孩子只曾经经历过残疾人作为灵感的对象。

en_test: We are not, to this kid --  and it's not his fault, I mean,  that's true for many of us.
zh_test: 对这个孩子来说，我们并不是什么激励对象， 这也不是他的错， 很多人都有这种想法。
M2M100: 我们不是,对这个孩子 - 这不是他的错,我说,这对我们很多人来说是真的。

en_test: For lots of us, disabled people are not our teachers  or our doctors or our manicurists.
zh_test: 对很多人来说，残障人士并不是老师， 医生或者美甲师。
M2M100: 对于我们很多人来说,残疾人不是我们的老师,也不是我们的医生,也不是我们的手术师。

en_test: We're not real people. We are there to inspire.
zh_test: 我们不是真实的人，我们的存在只是为了激励别人。
M2M100: 我们不是真正的人,我们在那里激励。

en_test: And in fact, I am sitting on this stage  looking like I do in this wheelchair,  and you are probably kind of expecting me  to inspire you. Right?   Yeah.
zh_test: 现在，我在这个讲台上， 坐着轮椅演讲， 你们可能多少也会期待我 能对你们有所激励，对吧？（观众笑声） 我说的没错吧。
M2M100: 事实上,我坐在这个舞台上看起来像我在这个轮椅上,你可能等着我激励你。

en_test: Well, ladies and gentlemen, I'm afraid  I'm going to disappoint you dramatically.
zh_test: 不过，女士们先生们，恐怕 我要让你们非常失望了。
M2M100: 好吧,夫人和先生们,我很害怕我会让你彻底失望。

en_test: I am not here to inspire you.
zh_test: 我在这里不是为了激励你们。
M2M100: 我不是来激励你。

en_test: I am here to tell you that we have been lied to  about disability.
zh_test: 我来这儿是想告诉你们 我们对残疾有错误的认识。
M2M100: 我在这里告诉你,我们被骗了关于残疾。

en_test: Yeah, we've been sold the lie  that disability is a Bad Thing, capital B, capital T.
zh_test: 没错，我们一直被错误的灌输 残疾是件坏事，很——糟——糕的事。

en_test: It's a bad thing, and to live with a disability  makes you exceptional.
zh_test: 这是件坏事，带着残缺生活 会让你与众不同。
M2M100: 这是一个糟糕的事情,生活在一个残疾人让你特别。

en_test: It's not a bad thing, and it doesn't  make you exceptional.
zh_test: 其实，这并不是件坏事， 也不会让你变得多出众。
M2M100: 这不是一件坏事,它不会让你特别。

en_test: And in the past few years, we've been able  to propagate this lie even further  via social media.
zh_test: 在过去的几年，这个谎言 通过社交媒体 被传的更广了。
M2M100: 在过去的几年里,我们已经能够通过社交媒体进一步传播这个谎言。

en_test: You may have seen images like this one:  "The only disability in life is a bad attitude."
zh_test: 你们可能看过这样的图片： ”生活中唯一的残缺就是消极的态度。“
M2M100: 你可能已经看到这样的图像:“生活中唯一的残疾是坏态度。

en_test: Or this one: "Your excuse is invalid." Indeed.
zh_test: 或者这个：”你的理由不成立。”
M2M100: 或說:「你們的道歉是無效的。

en_test: Or this one: "Before you quit, try!"
zh_test: 亦或者：“不要轻易放弃，继续尝试！”
M2M100: 或者说:“在你离开之前,试试!”

en_test: These are just a couple of examples,  but there are a lot of these images out there.
zh_test: 这只是其中的几个例子， 这样的图片还有很多。
M2M100: 这些只是几个例子,但这里有很多这些图像。

en_test: You know, you might have seen the one,  the little girl with no hands  drawing a picture with a pencil held in her mouth.
zh_test: 你们还可能看到过这个， 一个没有手臂的小女孩儿 把笔刁在嘴里画画。
M2M100: 你知道,你可能已经看到了那个没有手的小女孩在她的嘴里拿着铅笔画一张照片。

en_test: You might have seen a child running  on carbon fiber prosthetic legs.
zh_test: 你们可能也见过一个孩子借助 碳纤维义肢奔跑。
M2M100: 你可能已经看到一个孩子在碳纤维前列腿上奔跑。

en_test: And these images,  there are lots of them out there,  they are what we call inspiration porn.
zh_test: 类似这样的图片， 太多了， 我们管这些叫励志情色片。
M2M100: 这些图像,有很多,他们是我们称之为灵感色情的东西。

en_test: And I use the term porn deliberately,  because they objectify one group of people  for the benefit of another group of people.
zh_test: （观众笑声） 我故意用“情色片”这个词的， 因为他们为了另一群人的利益， 而把一群人物化。
M2M100: 我故意使用“色情”这个术语,因为它们反对一个群体的人为另一个群体的人利益。

en_test: So in this case, we're objectifying disabled people  for the benefit of nondisabled people.
zh_test: 现在，我们正在物化残障人士， 以满足非残障人士的利益。
M2M100: 因此,在这种情况下,我们将针对残疾人为无残疾人的利益。

en_test: The purpose of these images  is to inspire you, to motivate you,  so that we can look at them  and think, "Well, however bad my life is,  it could be worse.
zh_test: 这些图片是 想要鼓舞你们，激励你们， 这样我们看到这些残疾人的时候 就会想：“哦，我的生活再糟， 也还是有比我更糟的。
M2M100: 这些图像的目的是激励你,激励你,这样我们就可以看着它们,想:“好吧,我的生活越糟糕,它就越糟糕。

en_test: I could be that person."
zh_test: 还好我不是那个人。”
M2M100: “我可以是那个人。

en_test: But what if you are that person?
zh_test: 但如果你就是那个人呢？
M2M100: 但是,如果你是那个人呢?

en_test: I've lost count of the number of times that I've  been approached by strangers  wanting to tell me that they think I'm brave  or inspirational,  and this was long before my work  had any kind of public profile.
zh_test: 我已经记不清有几次， 有陌生人向我走过来， 想要告诉我他们认为我很勇敢， 很励志， 这还是在我没有 成为公众人物之前的事。
M2M100: 我失去了我被陌生人接近的次数,他们想告诉我他们认为我很勇敢或有启发性,这在我的工作有任何形式的公共资料之前很久。

en_test: They were just kind of congratulating me  for managing to get up in the morning  and remember my own name.   And it is objectifying.
zh_test: 他们只是因为我早上能够正常起床， 还能记着我自己的名字 而祝贺我。（观众笑声） 这就是物化。
M2M100: 他们只是为了祝贺我,因为我早上起床,记得我的名字,这是客观的。

en_test: These images, those images  objectify disabled people  for the benefit of nondisabled people.
zh_test: 这些图片 物化了残障人士，好让他们 能够激励非残障人士。
M2M100: 这些图像,这些图像对残疾人有利。

en_test: They are there so that you can look at them  and think that things aren't so bad for you,  to put your worries into perspective.
zh_test: 他们的存在，就在于能够让你们 庆幸自己过的还不坏， 把担心抛在脑后。
M2M100: 他们在那里,所以你可以看着他们,并认为事情对你不那么糟糕,把你的担忧放在前景。

en_test: And life as a disabled person  is actually somewhat difficult.
zh_test: 不过残障人士的生活 的确有些挑战。
M2M100: 作为一个残疾人,生活实际上有点困难。

en_test: We do overcome some things.
zh_test: 我们确实需要克服一些困难。
M2M100: 我们已经克服了一些事情。

en_test: But the things that we're overcoming  are not the things that you think they are.
zh_test: 不过我们需要克服的那些事 跟你们想像的不一样。
M2M100: 但是,我们正在克服的事情不是你认为它们是什么。

en_test: They are not things to do with our bodies.
zh_test: 这些事跟我们身体本身的缺陷没什么关系。
M2M100: 它们与我们的身体无关。

en_test: I use the term "disabled people" quite deliberately,  because I subscribe to what's called the social model of disability,  which tells us that we are more disabled  by the society that we live in  than by our bodies and our diagnoses.
zh_test: 我刻意使用“残疾人”这个词， 因为我可以接受这种社会普遍认同的残疾， 这让我们认识到，相比较我们身体本身的 缺陷和病症，我们所居住的社会 让我们更觉得自己是残疾人。
M2M100: 我用“残疾人”这个术语相当故意,因为我订阅所谓的社会残疾模式,这告诉我们我们比我们生活的社会更有残疾,而不是我们的身体和诊断。

en_test: So I have lived in this body a long time.
zh_test: 其实我像现在这样已经相当久了。
M2M100: 我在这个身体里生活了很长一段时间。

en_test: I'm quite fond of it.
zh_test: 感觉还挺不错的。
M2M100: 我对它很自豪。

en_test: It does the things that I need it to do,  and I've learned to use it to the best of its capacity  just as you have,  and that's the thing about those kids in those pictures as well.
zh_test: 我想做什么都能做， 而且我也知道怎么做那些力所能及的事儿， 就跟你们一样， 图片里的那些孩子也是这样。

en_test: They're not doing anything out of the ordinary.
zh_test: 他们并没做什么不同寻常的事儿。
M2M100: 他们不做平常的事情。

en_test: They are just using their bodies  to the best of their capacity.
zh_test: 他们只是最大程度的 让自己的身体发挥功能。

en_test: People, when they say, "You're an inspiration,"  they mean it as a compliment.

en_test: And I know why it happens.

en_test: It's because of the lie, it's because we've been sold  this lie that disability makes you exceptional.

zh_test: 其实不是。

en_test: And I know what you're thinking.
zh_test: 我知道你们在想什么。
M2M100: 我知道你在想什么。

en_test: You know, I'm up here bagging out inspiration,  and you're thinking, "Jeez, Stella,  aren't you inspired sometimes by some things?"
zh_test: 我在讲台上否认这种激励作用， 你们就会想：“天呐，史黛拉， 难道你就不会受其他事物的激励吗？”
M2M100: 你知道,我在这里抽出灵感,你想:“杰斯,斯特拉,你有时不是由某些事情灵感吗?”

en_test: And the thing is, I am.
zh_test: 事实是，我会。
M2M100: 事實就是,我是。

en_test: I learn from other disabled people all the time.
zh_test: 我无时无刻不在从其他残障人士身上学习。

en_test: I'm learning not that I am luckier than them, though.

M2M100: 但是,我不知道我比他们更幸运。

en_test: I am learning that it's a genius idea  to use a pair of barbecue tongs  to pick up things that you dropped.   I'm learning that nifty trick where you can charge  your mobile phone battery from your chair battery.
zh_test: 我学到的是，用烧烤棍 把你掉的东西捡起来 是个相当不错的主意。（观众笑声） 我觉得用电动轮椅的电池给手机充电 也是个绝妙的点子。
M2M100: 我正在学习,这是一个天才的想法,使用一对酒吧舌头来收拾你掉的东西,我正在学习那百个技巧,在那里你可以从你的椅子电池充电你的手机电池。

en_test: Genius.
zh_test: 太有才了！
M2M100: 天才。

en_test: We are learning from each others' strength and endurance,  not against our bodies and our diagnoses,  but against a world that exceptionalizes  and objectifies us.
zh_test: 我们互相学习彼此的坚强和隐忍， 不是对抗身体缺陷和疾病的坚强， 而是对抗整个社会区别对待我们， 物化我们的这种风气。
M2M100: 我们从彼此的力量和耐心中学习,不是反对我们的身体和诊断,而是反对一个让我们独特和客观的世界。

en_test: I really think that this lie that we've been sold  about disability is the greatest injustice.

en_test: It makes life hard for us.

en_test: And that quote, "The only disability in life  is a bad attitude,"  the reason that that's bullshit  is because it's just not true,  because of the social model of disability.
zh_test: 还有那句名言：”生活中唯一的残疾 就是消极的态度“， 这简直就是胡说八道， 因为事实根本不是这样 这只是社会认同的残疾。

en_test: No amount of smiling at a flight of stairs  has ever made it turn into a ramp.

en_test: No amount of standing in the middle of a bookshop  and radiating a positive attitude  is going to turn all those books into braille.

en_test: It's just not going to happen.
zh_test: 这都是不可能的事情。

en_test: I really want to live in a world  where disability is not the exception, but the norm.
zh_test: 我真心期待能活在这样一个世界里， 残疾不再是当成一种特殊， 仅仅是普通现象。
M2M100: 我真的想生活在一个残疾不是例外,而是正常的世界里。

en_test: sitting in her bedroom  watching "Buffy the Vampire Slayer"  isn't referred to as achieving anything  because she's doing it sitting down.
zh_test: 一个坐在卧室里 看”吸血鬼猎人巴菲” 的15岁女孩， 不会因为她能正常坐着 就被提名什么成就奖。
